Definition: a long-forgotten mistake from your past that could reappear at any time and rip your life apart, like a boomerang you tossed away years ago that's only just now looping back around, which you'd have no idea how to handle because you have no idea what it is.
Etymology: Fromfell, to cause to fall by delivering a blow +molechaser, a low swooping throw of a boomerang.
Example Sentences: I keep having this nightmare where my old emails are the Fellchaser finally catching up with me; Every time my phone rings from an unknown number, I get this jolt of panic, like it might be the Fellchaser making its move; Therapy's been mostly about learning to live with the idea that the Fellchaser might show up one day and choosing not to let that paralyze me now

Definition: set of living people who have known you all your life, all the way back to your infancy, before you had a clue who you were; a group that slowly shrinks as you get older, until the point when all of your closest confidants have only ever seen an abridged version of you, having joined your story somewhere in the middle of things, just as you did.
Etymology: Fromenter+entire+hood.
Example Sentences: My Enterhood is down to just my mom and my older cousin now, which feels weirdly lonely sometimes; When Grandpa died, it hit me that a whole chapter of my Enterhood just vanished overnight; At the reunion, sitting between my sister and our childhood neighbor, I realized I was the only one there who wasn't part of anyone else's Enterhood.

Definition: sadness of realizing that you're already forgetting sense memories of the departed—already struggling to hear their voice, picture the exact shade of their eyes, or call to mind the quirky little gestures you once knew by heart.
Etymology: Greek αμήν (amḗn), amen + μενταλιό (mentalió), locket. Pronounced "ah-men-tal-yoh."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk past their old house, that familiar wave of Amentalio hits me out of nowhere; Lately the photos help a little, but they also make the Amentalio feel sharper somehow; I thought I was doing okay, and then at the memorial service the Amentalio just crashed over me and I had to step outside for air

Definition: feeling the loneliness of having to keep a secret to yourself.
Etymology: Old Englishhidil, hiding place. Pronounced "hid-ld."
Example Sentences: I could tell from the way she stared out the window that she was really hiddled about whatever happened last summer; He joked around with everyone at the party, but later he admitted he'd never felt more hiddled in his life; That song hits so hard when you're already feeling a bit hiddled about things you can't talk about.

Definition: tendency for future goals and benchmarks to feel huge when viewed in advance, only to fade into banality as soon as you've achieved them—finally reaching the top of the ladder, only to notice it circling back around like a hamster wheel.
Etymology: A variation onredshiftandblueshift, the astronomical processes that make objects moving away look redder than they really are, and objects moving toward you look bluer.
Example Sentences: I'm trying to celebrate this promotion, but the Grayshift is already kicking in and I'm just thinking about the next title; It helps to write down how excited I am now so I have something to look back on when the Grayshift makes this milestone feel tiny; We need to design our goals so they're meaningful day-to-day, not just at the finish line, otherwise the Grayshift will eat all the joy out of them.

Definition: a state of confusion when your own internal sense of time doesn't seem to match that of the calendar—knowing that something just happened though it apparently took place seven years ago, or that you somehow built up a decade of memories in the span of only a year and a half.
Etymology: Greek εχθές (echthés), yesterday +αἴσθησις(aísthēsis), sensation. Pronounced "ek-thee-zhuh."
Example Sentences: I always get this weird echthesia when I visit my old college campus, like I graduated both yesterday and a lifetime ago; Her journal entries are full of little notes about bouts of echthesia, especially around anniversaries and holidays; The movie messed with my echthesia so badly that I walked out of the theater convinced the last three years of my life had folded into a single afternoon.

Definition: frustration of being stuck inside your own head, unable to see your face or read your body language in context, only ever guessing how you might be coming across—which makes you think of yourself as a detached observer squinting out at a lushly painted landscape, though to everyone else you seem woven right into the canvas.
Etymology: Frompoint of view+ism. Blessed are the slugs, whose eyes are held aloft on wriggling stalks, just tall enough to see their entire bodies in context. Pronounced "poh-viz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Lately my Povism has been so bad that I keep replaying every conversation in my head, trying to figure out how I sounded; Sometimes journaling actually helps with the Povism a bit, like it gives me a mirror for how I come across; When my Povism kicks in during meetings, I have to remind myself that nobody is analyzing me as hard as I am analyzing myself

Definition: a state of exhaustion with how cruel people can be, freely undercutting each other in ways that seem petty and gratuitous—which can sometimes trigger a countervailing sense of gratitude for things that are kind, sincere, forgiving, or unabashedly joyful.
Etymology: Ancient Greek ἄνθρωπος (ánthrōpos), humanity + ὀδύνη (odúnē), sorrow, anguish, pain. Pronounced "an-thruh-din-ee-uh."
Example Sentences: Lately my anthrodynia has been so bad that I've had to log off social media for a while; After that meeting, the anthrodynia hit me hard, but then our intern's small act of kindness kind of pulled me back; I get these waves of anthrodynia, and then something simple like a neighbor helping carry groceries reminds me why I still care about people at all.

Definition: bitter disappointment upon finding no new messages after spending hours out of contact, as if the world had barely even noticed you had left.
Etymology: From the tendency of spacefaring objects to heat up upon reentering the atmosphere.
Example Sentences: After my weekend camping trip, the Burn Upon Reentry hit hard when I finally turned my phone back on; I used to think Burn Upon Reentry only happened after vacations, but even a long flight with no Wi‑Fi can trigger it; If you're prone to Burn Upon Reentry, maybe turn your phone on around close friends so it doesn't sting as much.

Definition: a moment you instantly wish you could take back, feeling a pulse of dread right after crossing the point of no return—a blurted confession, a hurled insult, a final decision you'd been waffling over for months— wanting to take just one step backward in time, reverting to the way things used to be, in the halcyon days of just a minute ago.
Etymology: Fromrue, to regret +bourrasque, a tempest. Pronounced "rask."
Example Sentences: I had this huge rasque right after I hit send" on that email to my boss; Every time I walk past that restaurant where we broke up

Definition: a sense memory you've mulled over so thoroughly that it's become totally drained of emotion—having replayed an old song to death, over- binged a favorite sitcom, or spent too much time in the old neighborhood —inadvertently depleting a wellspring of nostalgia by watering it down with newer connotations.
Etymology: Fromwallow, to indulge or soak in something +away. Pronounced "wol-uh-wey."
Example Sentences: I tried listening to that album again last night, but it just felt like pure Walloway at this point; Every time I drive past my old high school now, it's all Walloway—no butterflies, no lump in my throat, just static; I don't rewatch that show anymore, I'm scared I'll turn those cozy memories into Walloway like I did with our summer road trip playlist.

Definition: unable to settle the question of whether you're doing okay in life; feeling torn between conflicting value systems and moveable goalposts, which makes you long for someone to come along and score your progress in discrete and measurable units—points, dollars, friends, followers, or a grade point average—which may not clear up where you're going but would at least reassure you that you're one step closer to getting there.
Etymology: Fromaddled, muddled or unclear +worth.
Example Sentences: Lately I've been in such a weird Addleworth that even small decisions like what job to apply for feel impossibly loaded; I think turning thirty just flipped some internal switch of panic; When I scroll through everyone's highlight reels on social media, the Addleworth hits so hard I end up closing the app and just staring at the ceiling

Definition: a pang of shame when an embarrassing memory from adolescence rushes back into your head from out of nowhere, which is somehow no less painful even if nobody else remembers it happened in the first place.
Etymology: Acronym of The Hell Was I Thinking?
Example Sentences: I got this random thwit in the middle of the meeting and completely lost my train of thought; Every time I walk past that old bus stop, I get a little thwit about how I used to dress in high school; She just laughed and said, Had a thwit

Definition: fear that you're utterly powerless to change the world around you, looking on helplessly at so many intractable problems out there—slums that sprawl from horizon to horizon, daily headlines of an unstoppable civil war, a slick of air pollution blanketing the skyline—which makes the act of trying to live your own life feel grotesque and self-indulgent, as if you're rubbernecking through the world.
Etymology: Sloveniannemočen, powerless. Pronounced "nih-moh-shah."
Example Sentences: Lately my Nemotia has been so intense that I have to limit how much news I read just to get through the day; Sometimes talking with friends who actually volunteer and organize things helps take the edge off the Nemotia a bit; I could feel that familiar Nemotia creeping in as we drove past the flooded neighborhoods, like I was just a spectator in someone else's disaster

Definition: an ill-fated attempt to reenact a beloved memory years later, returning to a place that once felt like home, only to find it now feels uncannily off, like walking through a wax museum of your own childhood.
Etymology: Dutchkier, fissure or narrow opening, as in the midpoint of an hourglass. Pronounced "keer."
Example Sentences: I knew planning that trip back to our old summer camp was going to turn into a total Keir, but I went along anyway; Every time I walk past my high school and think about going in, I stop myself because I can feel the Keir coming a mile away; She warned us it might be a Keir, but we still booked the tickets and tried to recreate that last perfect weekend together.

Definition: habit of telling yourself that just one tweak could solve all of your problems—if only you had the right haircut, if only you found the right group of friends, if only you made a little more money, if only he noticed you, if only she loved you back, if only you could find the time, if only you were confident—which leaves you feeling perpetually on the cusp of a better life, hanging around the top of the slide waiting for one little push.
Etymology: Fromjust, only, simply, merely +jousting, a sport won by positioning the tip of your lance at just the right spot, at just the right second. Pronounced "juhst-ing."
Example Sentences: I've been doing so much Justing lately that I'm exhausted by my own thoughts; Every time something goes wrong, she slips right back into Justing instead of actually changing anything; We promised each other we'd stop the late-night Justing and start making real plans instead.

Definition: peculiar quality of never having chosen to be born, which is shared by everyone else around you; the curious awareness that even though earthly life might be the most exciting party in the universe, somehow everyone in attendance had been dragged here by a friend or stumbled in by accident.
Etymology: Greek απονέμω (aponémo), to bestow. Pronounced "ap-uh-nee-mee-uh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes that late-night Aponemia hits me when I'm staring at the ceiling, and suddenly my whole life feels like an afterparty I never RSVP'd to; Her novel captures that quiet Aponemia you feel at family reunions, when everyone's chatting and laughing but you're not sure how any of you ended up here; We were joking about Aponemia over coffee, and it somehow made us both feel oddly comforted, like we were in on the same cosmic misunderstanding.

Definition: anxiously excited to introduce a friend to something you think is amazing—a classic album, a favorite restaurant, a TV show they're lucky enough to watch for the very first time—which prompts you to continually poll their face waiting for the inevitable rush of awe, only to cringe when you discover all the work's flaws shining through for the very first time.
Etymology: Old Englishlicode, it pleased [you] +psychotic. Pronounced "lahy-kot-ic."
Example Sentences: I was so licotic about showing her my favorite movie that I barely watched the screen and just kept checking her reaction; By the time the credits rolled, my licotic energy had totally backfired and all I could see were the awkward plot holes; He gets almost painfully licotic whenever he plays someone that old indie album, hovering by the speakers and asking, Isn't this part incredible?""

Definition: half-forlorn, half-escapist ache of a train whistle howling in the distance at night.
Etymology: Fromamen, "so be it" +neurosis, an anxious state +amanuensis, an assistant who helps transcribe newly composed music. A train whistle is the sound of air being forced across a gap, which serves as a poignant reminder of all the gaps in your life. Pronounced "ah-men-nyoo-roh-sis."
Example Sentences: Between Living and Dreaming

Definition: a state of unease prompted by people who seem to like you too much, which makes you wonder if they must have you confused with someone else—someone flawless, selfless, or easy to understand from a distance —feeling vaguely disappointed that they're unwilling to spend the time it takes getting to know the real you.
Etymology: Ancient Greek εἴδωλον (eídōlon), a phantom image of an ideal form. Pronounced "duh-loh-nee- uh."
Example Sentences: I always get this weird Dolonia when my coworkers compliment me like I'm some kind of genius after a basic presentation; That text he sent was so over-the-top sweet that it triggered my Dolonia, like he was talking to some ideal version of me instead of the actual mess I am; Meeting my girlfriend's parents was fine, but the way they instantly adored me just cranked my Dolonia up to eleven.

Definition: state of feeling trapped inside your own subjective tastes—not knowing why you find certain things beautiful or ugly, only that you do —wishing you could remove the sociopsychological lenses from your eyes so you could see the beauty in anything and be moved to tears by the smell of burning garbage, the aria of a screaming toddler, or a neon Elvis painted on black velvet.
Etymology: Fromaesthetic, concerned with beauty or artistry +orthosis, a brace that artificially straightens a weak or injured part of the body. Pronounced "es-thoh-sis."
Example Sentences: Sometimes my aesthosis hits so hard that I can't tell if I actually like this song or if I've just been trained to; Her whole art project is basically a diary of her aesthosis, and honestly it's kind of unsettling to look at; On bad days, the aesthosis makes me feel like I'm stuck inside my own head while everyone else is just casually enjoying the world.

Definition: an unexpected surge of emotion in response to a seemingly innocuous trigger—the distinctive squeal of a rusty fence, a key change in an old pop song, the hint of a certain perfume—which feels all the more intense because you can't quite pin it down.
Etymology: Fromheart+spur, a spike on a heel that urges a horse to move forward.
Example Sentences: I got this weird heartspur in the grocery store when I heard that old jingle playing over the speakers; Every time the bus brakes squeal like that, I get this little heartspur that takes me right back to middle school; The movie was fine, but that one chord in the soundtrack hit me with a heartspur so strong I almost had to leave the theater.

Definition: inability to decide how much sympathy your situation really deserves, knowing that so many people have it far worse and others far better, that some people would need years of therapy to overcome what you have, while others would barely think to mention it in their diary that day.
Etymology: Frenchsoucis, worries +insouciance, indifference. Who knows what an ordinary person should be expected to handle? Perhaps human life is so tough that we all deserve some sympathy. Or perhaps it's such a privilege to be alive at all that none of us has the right to complain. Pronounced "in-soo-siz-uhm."
Example Sentences: I've been stuck in this weird insoucism about my breakup—like, am I allowed to be this upset or am I being dramatic?; Her journal entry last night was basically three pages of pure insoucism, just her spiraling about whether her problems even count as problems; Talking to my therapist actually helped me name that feeling as insoucism, which made it a little easier to talk about without instantly minimizing everything

Definition: fear of irrevocable actions and irreversible processes—knowing that a colorful shirt will fade a little more with every wash, that your tooth enamel is wearing away molecule by molecule, never to grow back.
Etymology: Greek μονόδρομος (monódromos), one-way street + -φοβία (-phobía), fear. Pronounced "noh-droh-foh-bee-uh."
Example Sentences: I didn't realize how bad my nodrophobia was until I spent an hour agonizing over whether to click permanently delete" on my emails; My therapist says the nodrophobia might be why I avoid starting long TV series—I can't stop thinking about the time I'm committing and never getting back; Ever since the accident

Definition: a disconcerting cluster of endings that all seem to happen at once; a random barrage of departures and closures and divorces and series finales and celebrity deaths, which leaves you anxiously aware that the author of your story seems to be wrapping up an awful lot of loose ends.
Etymology: Ancient Greek ἐπὶ- (epi-), on top of + ὕστριξ (hystrix), a porcupine. To sit on a porcupine is to feel the pain of too many endings all at once. Pronounced "ih-pis-triks."
Example Sentences: I've been in such a weird Epistrix lately—my lease ended, my favorite show wrapped, and two coworkers quit in the same week; It's not just you, the whole friend group feels like we're in an Epistrix right now, like everything's winding down at once; After that Epistrix last fall, I've been bracing myself whenever a bunch of small endings start piling up again

Definition: act of deliberately refusing to learn the scientific explanations of things out of fear that it'll ruin the magic—turning flower petals into tacky billboards, decoding birdsong into trash talk, defracting a rainbow back inside its tiny prism.
Etymology: Danishforklaring, explanation. Pronounced "fohr-kleer-ing."
Example Sentences: I used to think my foreclearing was harmless, but now I wish I'd paid more attention in physics class; Her whole vibe is cozy crafts, fairy lights, and a kind of gentle foreclearing whenever conversations get too technical; There's a difference between healthy curiosity and the kind of foreclearing that makes you dismiss anything that doesn't feel whimsical enough.

Definition: nagging sense that no matter how many days you spend exploring a foreign country, you never quite manage to step foot in it—instead floating high above the culture like a diver over a reef, too dazzled by its exotic quirks to notice its problems and complexities and banalities, while drawing from the heavy tank of assumptions that you carry on your back wherever you go.
Etymology: Fromvulture, an animal that hovers high over its prey +culture shock, the confusion of having to adjust to a culture different than the one you're used to.
Example Sentences: By the end of our two-week tour of Thailand, the vulture shock hit me so hard I just wanted to sit in a laundromat and people-watch instead of visiting another temple; She wrote this long blog post about her vulture shock in Paris, realizing she'd spent more time photographing croissants than actually talking to anyone who lived there; After my third once-in-a-lifetime" trip this year

Definition: satisfaction of things worn down by time—broken-in baseball mitts, the shiny snout of a lucky bronze pig, or footprints ground deep into floorboards by generations of kneeling monks.
Etymology: Italianliso, worn down, threadbare +oliato, oiled. Pronounced "lih-soh-lee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk into my grandparents' house, that wave of Lisolia hits me before I even take off my shoes; You can polish the place all you want, but if you rip out those old floorboards you'll lose all the Lisolia that makes this café special; I know the new stadium is nicer, but the old one had so much Lisolia it felt wrong when they tore it down.

Definition: feeling the primal satisfaction of being needed by someone, which makes you feel that much more rooted to the world, even if the roots belong to someone else.
Etymology: Fromtender, emotionally raw +hooks, a tool for binding one thing to another. Compareon tenterhooks, which is a state of anxious suspense.
Example Sentences: Ever since my sister had her baby, she's kept me on tenderhooks with all her late-night calls asking for advice; I didn't realize how much I missed feeling that way until my old team lead texted, We really need you on this project

Definition: instinctive tendency to see someone as you knew them in their youth—a burned-in image of grass-stained knees, graffitied backpacks, or handfuls of birthday cake, superimposed on an adult with a mortgage, or children of their own.
Etymology: In audio recording,backmaskingis a technique wherein a sound is deliberately recorded backward, so it's only intelligible when played in reverse.
Example Sentences: Every time I run into my old camp counselor at the grocery store, the backmasking hits so hard I almost expect her to ask if I've put on sunscreen; At the reunion, there was this weird backmasking effect where the CEO in a tailored suit was still, in my head, the kid who cheated at dodgeball; Seeing my older brother cradle his newborn, I couldn't stop the backmasking from kicking in—I kept flashing back to him with scraped elbows and a bowl cut.

Definition: irrational fear that someone you know is angry at you, that as soon as you wander into the room, you'll be faced with a barrage of questions that gradually escalates into a frenzy of outrage, for reasons that you don't understand.
Etymology: In Ancient Greek mythology, theManiaeare spirits who personified insanity, along with their sisterLyssa, who was known for erupting into rages. Pronounced "lis-uh-mey-nee-uh."
Example Sentences: I almost canceled the party because my Lyssamania was telling me everyone secretly hated me for no reason; She texted me "we need to talk" and my Lyssamania went into overdrive until I saw it was just about weekend plans; Therapy's been helping me recognize when it's just Lyssamania talking instead of any real problem with my friends.

Definition: a complicated feeling of envy and admiration for people younger than you—their eyes shining with energy, their futures rich with potential, their confidence smooth and untouched like a freshly opened jar of peanut butter, which you simultaneously want to preserve forever and gleefully undercut.
Etymology: Latintiros, beginners, new recruits +jealousy. Pronounced "teer-uh-see."
Example Sentences: Every time I watch my interns present, I'm hit with this wave of Tirosy that I have to hide behind a polite smile; Seeing my little cousin graduate college stirred up such intense Tirosy that I ended up rambling advice at her all night; I try to be supportive of the new hires, but the Tirosy kicks in hard when they talk about their five-year plans like anything is still possible.

Definition: proud of a certain scar on your body, which is like an autograph signed to you by a world grateful for your continued willingness to play with her, even if it hurts.
Etymology: Fromscab+fabulous.
Example Sentences: I used to hide the line on my knee, but now I'm totally scabulous about it after everything I went through; That photo of her at the beach, laughing and showing off her surgery marks, is the most scabulous thing I've ever seen; He rolled up his sleeve in this super scabulous way, like, Yeah

Definition: curious to know what someone else would do if they were in your shoes, eager to watch another actor put their own spin on the character of You—carrying your body differently, speaking in a tone you never use, saying and doing things you didn't even know were an option—a performance that might well end in disaster but would at least remind you that there are many different ways to play this role, even though you tend to assume you're just reading the lines as written.
Etymology: From vicarious, but without the I. Pronounced "vik-er-uhs."
Example Sentences: I'm feeling weirdly vicarous about this job offer—like I almost want to see what you'd do if you were the one getting it instead of me; Watching my understudy rehearse gave me this intense, vicarous thrill, like I was seeing an alternate version of my own life play out; When I told my therapist about it, she laughed and said my vicarous obsession with how my brother would handle my problems might be a way of avoiding making my own choices

Definition: longing to see how other people live their lives when they're not in public; wishing you could tune in to the raw feed of another human existence, in all its messiness and solitude—shimmying in place while brushing their teeth, squabbling over where to put the shoes, talking out their problems on solitary commutes—if only to give you something to compare your own life against, and figure out whether you're bizarrely normal or normally bizarre.
Etymology: Fromken, one's range of knowledge +keep-away, a game in which one player tries to intercept a ball being tossed back and forth by two others. Pronounced "ken-uh-wey."
Example Sentences: Sometimes my kenaway kicks in so hard that I end up people-watching at the café for an extra hour; I get this weird kenaway whenever I pass apartment buildings at night and see little snapshots of other people's lives through the windows; I had to mute that vlog channel because it was feeding my kenaway way too much, and I started comparing every tiny detail of my day to theirs

Definition: fear that your emotions might feel profound but are crudely biological, less to do with meaning and philosophy than with hormones, endorphins, sleep cycles, and blood sugar—any of which might easily be tweaked to induce unfalsifiable feelings of joy, depression, bloodlust, or kinship, or even a spiritual transcendence of your physical body.
Etymology: Acronym of the supposed "happy chemicals" Dopamine, Oxytocin, Serotonin, and Endorphins +in absentia, something done in your absence. Pronounced "in-duh-sen-shah" or "in-doh-sen-tyah."
Example Sentences: something done in your absence. Pronounced "in-duh-sen-shah" or "in-doh-sen-tyah.""

Definition: dread of finally pursuing a lifelong dream, which requires you to put your true abilities out there to be tested on the open savannah, no longer protected inside the terrarium of hopes and delusions that you started up in kindergarten and kept sealed as long as you could.
Etymology: GermanZiel, goal +Schmerz, pain. Pronounced "zeel-shmerts."
Example Sentences: Ich dachte, ich wäre total bereit für dieses Buchprojekt, aber als der Verlagsvertrag kam, hat mich der Zielschmerz so hart getroffen, dass ich ihn erst mal eine Woche nicht unterschrieben habe; Ganz ehrlich, mein größter Kampf ist nicht der Zeitmangel, sondern der Zielschmerz, jedes Mal, wenn ich meinem Traum wirklich näherkomme; Als sie das Stipendium tatsächlich gewonnen hat, war ihr erster Reflex nicht Freude, sondern purer Zielschmerz, weil sie wusste, dass es jetzt ernst wird.

Definition: tipping point when your brain becomes so overwhelmed with tasks you need to do, you feel too guilty to put anything off until later, prioritizing every little thing at the top of the list, leaving you immobilized.
Etymology: During the lunar descent of Apollo 11, the "1202" alarm sounded just before landing, indicating that the computer was receiving more data than it could process. Pronounced "twelve oh two."
Example Sentences: Frustration-Overwhelm; Complexity-Confusion

Definition: a mysterious aura of loneliness you feel in certain places; the palpable weight of all the lonely people secretly holed up in their houses and apartments, with a flickering blue glow cast up on their walls—so many of whom might just want someone to talk to, or just want to feel needed, and could be that for each other if only they could somehow connect.
Etymology: Short for "All the lonely people," from the song "Eleanor Rigby" by the Beatles. Pronounced "al-uh-pee."
Example Sentences: Loneliness-Detachment; Connection-Relation; Familiar-Unfamiliar

Definition: to mindlessly perform a tedious task that nobody will ever notice, required by a bureaucracy that nobody fully owns, in pursuit of outcomes that nobody really wants.
Etymology: Fromscrow, to work hard +scroff, useless bits of leftover material +cog, a tiny forgettable element in a complicated machine. Pronounced "skrawg."
Example Sentences: I've got to stay late and scrough through these forms before the audit tomorrow; Every Friday turns into an hour of pure scroughing just to keep the higher-ups happy; If this is just more scrough for that committee, I'm not touching it without overtime pay

Definition: sudden awareness that you're finally over someone, noticing that the same voice that once triggered a cocktail of emotions now evokes nothing at all—as if your brain had returned the last box of their things and your heart had quietly changed its locks.
Etymology: Fromlack, missing something +blackout, when a spark abruptly goes away.
Example Sentences: I had this weird lackout the other day when I saw his name pop up on Instagram and just scrolled past without thinking twice; It wasn't some big dramatic moment, more like a quiet lackout that hit me while we were talking and I realized I was just… bored, not hurt; After months of overanalyzing everything, the lackout finally kicked in at her birthday party—I heard her laugh across the room and felt absolutely nothing.

Definition: anxious to imagine how many times you must've barely avoided catastrophe—the morning you missed the bus that later went on to crash, the day you stayed onshore when it was a bit too rough out there—which makes it feel like something of a fluke that you've survived this long, as if you're on an unbroken streak of coin flips, heads after heads after heads, wondering when your luck is going to run out.
Etymology: Old Englishnigh, almost +nihil, nothing. Pronounced "nahy-lis."
Example Sentences: I get really Nilous whenever I think about all the tiny decisions that could've gone the other way; Last night's storm had me feeling weirdly Nilous about that hike we almost took; She laughed it off, but you could tell she went a bit Nilous after hearing about the accident on the highway she usually takes.

Definition: frustration of knowing how neatly you embody a certain stereotype, without even intending to; the sense of bafflement at the extent to which we all seem to hew to certain tropes, each looking pretty much how you'd expect them to look, as if we're all trick-or-treating through society wearing one of a handful of premade costumes, because we're tired of answering the question, "What are you supposed to be?"
Etymology: Ancient Greek μῖμος (mîmos), imitator, actor + μῖσος (mîsos), hatred. Pronounced "mim-ee-oh-mee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time someone guesses my major on the first try, I get this wave of mimeomia and want to change my whole wardrobe; She laughed about her mimeomia when the barista said, Let me guess

Definition: a condition in which you keep scanning faces in a crowd looking for a specific person who would have no reason to be there, as if your brain is checking to see whether they're still in your life, subconsciously patting its emotional pockets before it leaves for the day.
Etymology: From theWhere's Waldo?series of picture books, or in some countries,Where's Wally?, in which the reader tries to spot one specific person somewhere in a massive crowd. Pronounced "wawl-doh-zhuh" or "wawl-doh-see-uh."
Example Sentences: I thought I was over him, but the Waldosia hit me hard at the airport when I caught myself searching every face in the security line; Lately the Waldosia's been worse—every time I'm at a concert, I keep half-expecting her to be in the crowd; It's funny how a random street festival can trigger full-on Waldosia, like my brain just flips into scan mode without asking me first.

Definition: aware that you'll only ever be a certain age relative to your loved ones, only seeing them from one arbitrary angle across the decades— never knowing your mother in her rebellious youth, never seeing your grandkid as anything other than a kid—because even though your life spans do happen to overlap, they'll never quite line up.
Etymology: Fromclock+wise, pointedly aware of.
Example Sentences: I got all weirdly clockwise at my grandma's birthday party, realizing I'll only ever know her as an old woman and never as the wild teenager she used to be; Looking at my baby photos next to my mom's, I had this sudden clockwise feeling that our timelines just skim past each other but never really match up; When my nephew called me old

Definition: a place that seems to hold profound significance to everyone else but you—the sacred temple of some other faith, a random fence post festooned with flowers, a crowd cheering for a team you've never heard of—which leaves you trying to coax yourself into feeling something anyway, like inserting your house key into a random lock just to feel if something clicks.
Etymology: Fromholy, sacred or religiously revered +-ette, denoting an imitation of the real thing. Pronounced "hoh-lee-et."
Example Sentences: I didn't want to admit it, but standing in front of the monument was pure Holiette for me, while everyone else was wiping away tears; That whole championship parade felt like Holiette—I kept clapping along, hoping the excitement would finally rub off; She dragged me to that famous overlook at sunrise, and I just stood there in quiet Holiette, pretending the view meant more to me than it really did.

Definition: fear of major life changes, even ones you've been anticipating for years; the dread of leaving behind the bright and ordinary world you know, stepping out into that liminal space before the next stage of life begins, like the dark and rattling void between adjoining metro cars.
Etymology: Malagasylelosy, snail, which is a creature that carries many twists and turns wherever it goes, trying in vain to outrun them. Pronounced "ehl-uh-see."
Example Sentences: I've had a weird wave of Elosy creeping up on me ever since I signed the lease for the new place; She joked that her Elosy was louder than the graduation ceremony itself, but you could tell she wasn't entirely kidding; On the train ride to the airport, his Elosy hit so hard he almost texted to say he wasn't coming.

Definition: wish that you could see statistics overlaid on every person you encounter—checking the signal strength of their compatibility, a measure of their trustworthiness, or even just an emoji that tells you how they're really feeling.
Etymology: From the two symbols of binary code,1and0, denoting "on" or "off" +I am. Pronounced "ahy-yo-yuh."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk into a party and don't know anyone, my Ioia kicks in so hard; I caught myself wishing for Ioia on my dating apps too, just a tiny icon next to each profile; After that disastrous group project, my Ioia is off the charts whenever I get assigned new teammates now

Definition: a dizzying sense of awe at the sheer scale of modern society—looking out at a city so vast and complex it can barely be mapped, with millions of miles of roads and power lines and water mains that must be continually repaired and replaced every few years, feeding a labyrinth of supply chains and regulations and contracts and algorithms—a system so massive that individual people seem almost beside the point, that if everybody were to vanish all at once, the city would sigh and carry on its business.
Etymology: Fromlabyrinth, a maze of tortuous complexity +vertigo, the whirling sensation of looking down from great heights. Compare Spanishlátigo, whip. Pronounced "lat-i-goh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I get this wave of Latigo just staring out the window of the plane as we're flying over the city at night; Walking through Times Square for the first time hit me with such intense Latigo that I had to just stop and lean against a wall for a minute; After a week in that megacity, the Latigo didn't really fade—it just became the background hum of my thoughts.

Definition: a feeling of queasiness while offering someone advice, knowing they might well face a totally different set of constraints and capabilities, any of which might propel them to a wildly different outcome—which makes you wonder if all of your hard-earned wisdom is fundamentally nontransferable, like handing someone a gift card in your name that probably expired years ago.
Etymology: Middle Englishrede, advice +pedesis, the random motion of particles. Pronounced "ruh-dee-sis."
Example Sentences: I always get this wave of Redesis halfway through giving career advice to my younger cousins; Lila texted me later saying she appreciated the talk, even though she could tell I was battling some serious Redesis the whole time; After years of mentoring, he's learned to pause, acknowledge the Redesis, and then just share his story without pretending it's some universal blueprint

Definition: compulsively turning away from works of art you find frustratingly, nauseatingly good—wanting to shut off the film and leave the theater, or devour a book only in maddening little chunks—because it resonates at precisely the right frequency to rattle you to your core, which makes it mildly uncomfortable to be yourself.
Etymology: Frombitching, markedly good +fitch, the European polecat, an animal that often cripples its prey by piercing its brain with its teeth, before storing it alive in its burrow to return and eat sometime later.
Example Sentences: I had to keep pausing the movie because I was totally Fitching halfway through that monologue; She said she was Fitching so hard with that novel that she could only read a few pages a day; By the third song of the album, we were both Fitching and just sat there in stunned silence, unable to hit play on the next track.

Definition: habit of taking stock of your life on the occasion of your birthday—letting it serve as a kind of internal referendum on all your goals and qualities and relationships and accomplishments so far—which makes you want to dress just a little nicer that day, as if you're standing before a parole board that convenes once a year to adjudicate your release from childhood.
Etymology: Fromcandling, a method of egg inspection in which an egg is backlit with a candle flame to reveal how the chick is growing, or if it's there at all.
Example Sentences: I've been doing some serious candling this week, and it's making me rethink where I want to be by next year; Every year on my birthday I end up candling without even meaning to, then I either feel super motivated or mildly panicked; She said she's dreading her thirtieth because the candling is going to hit so much harder this time around

Definition: state of being simultaneously entranced and unsettled by the vastness of the cosmos, which makes your deepest concerns feel laughably quaint, yet vanishingly rare.
Etymology: Fromgalaxy, a gravitationally bound system of millions of stars +agog, awestruck. Pronounced "gal-uh-gawg."
Example Sentences: Every time we camp out in the desert and the sky actually gets dark, I just lie there in total Galagog and forget what I was stressed about; That documentary on black holes hit me with such intense Galagog that I had to pause it and go for a walk; I chase that feeling of Galagog on long night drives, windows down, radio low, just letting the stars make everything else feel far away

Definition: an odd interval of blankness you feel after something big happens to you but before you feel the resulting emotional reaction—stunned by a sudden loss, a stroke of luck, or an unexpected visitor—like those tension-filled seconds between a flash of lightning and the thunderclap that follows, which gives you a hint of how near you are to the coming storm.
Etymology: Fromtarry, to be late to react, or linger in expectation +carry on. Pronounced "tar-ee-uhn."
Example Sentences: I just sat there in pure Tarrion after reading the email, not even sure whether to laugh or cry; You could see the Tarrion in his eyes when the doctor gave him the news, like his brain hadn't caught up yet; That whole car ride home was just Tarrion and silence, both of us waiting for the feelings to finally crash in.

Definition: atmosphere of camaraderie when people are stuck together in a certain place—a stalled elevator, a shelter during a storm, the sleeper car of a train—which leaves them no other option but to be present with each other, with nowhere else to go, and nobody else to be.
Etymology: Fromlocked up+fullheartedness.
Example Sentences: That snowed‑in weekend at the cabin had this weird lockheartedness that made total strangers feel like old friends; You could feel the lockheartedness on that overnight train—by midnight everyone was sharing snacks and life stories; I kind of miss the lockheartedness of those late‑night shifts when the whole team was trapped in the office during deadlines.

Definition: post-distraction effort to recall the reason you're feeling particularly anxious or angry or excited, trying to retrace your sequence of thoughts like a kid gathering the string of a downed kite.
Etymology: Ancient Greek νέμειν (némein), to give what is due + Latindementia, without mind. Pronounced "ne-men-shuh."
Example Sentences: I was halfway through my commute when this wave of stress hit me, and I had to stop and do some serious nementia to figure out what had set me off; Lately my nementia has been exhausting—every time I get worked up, I end up mentally rewinding my whole day; She laughed and said, Give me a second

Definition: feeling the haunting solitude of extremely remote places—a clearing in the forest, a windswept field of snow, a rest area in the middle of nowhere—which makes you feel like you've just intruded on a conversation that had nothing to do with you, where even the gravel beneath your feet and the trees overhead are holding themselves back to a pointed, inhospitable silence.
Etymology: Fromwild+dread. Pronounced "wil-drid."
Example Sentences: I got this sudden wave of Wildred when we pulled off at that empty gas station in the desert at 2 a.m.; Standing alone on the frozen lake at dusk, I was hit by this deep Wildred that made me want to whisper instead of talk; The hike was beautiful, but that last stretch through the abandoned logging road was pure Wildred, and I couldn't shake it for hours afterward

Definition: terror of the blank page, which can feel both liberating and confining, in both the limitlessness of its potential and the looseness of its boundaries.
Etymology: Japanese 空の (kara-no), blank. Pronounced "kar-uh-noi-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time I open a new notebook, the Karanoia hits so hard I just end up doodling in the margins instead of writing; She swears a glass of wine and a strict 10-minute timer are the only things that can cut through her Karanoia; After the workshop, my Karanoia eased up a bit because they made us fill the page with anything, even nonsense, just so it wasn't empty anymore.

Definition: malaise that results from having unlimited access to something, which only seems to drain away its value—a cheat code that ruins the game, a camera that holds a million random snapshots, or having so much free time that all your goals dissolve in it.
Etymology: Maoriango, open + Latinangō, I cause pain or distress. Pronounced "ang-goh-sis."
Example Sentences: Ever since I went fully remote and stopped keeping a schedule, the Angosis has been hitting me hard in the afternoons; She thought getting that all‑access pass would feel amazing, but by day three the Angosis had already started to creep in; We should set some limits on ourselves this weekend so the whole trip doesn't just dissolve into Angosis and scrolling.

Definition: frustrated that you can't force yourself to remember something, even though it's right on the tip of your tongue—wishing you could simply rifle through your own files directly, rather than having to toss random scraps to your team of mental archivists, who evidently need hours to sift through the pile before they come up with an answer, just as you're falling asleep.
Etymology: Frompither, to dig lightly. Pronounced "pith-erd."
Example Sentences: I'm so pithered right now—I can picture the actor's face perfectly, but his name just will not come to me; She got all pithered during the meeting, snapping her fingers and staring at the ceiling, trying to recall the term she'd used in her report; Lying in bed, totally pithered, I finally remembered the password I'd been struggling with all afternoon and had to get up to write it down.

Definition: wondering what our ancestors would think of all this; haunted by the awareness that our world was designed by the dead, who spent their lives trying to flesh out every detail but never got to see how it all turned out—who might well think of the present as an impossible dream, a missed opportunity, or the end of the world as they knew it.
Etymology: Fromantecedent, predecessor or ancestor +anxious. Pronounced "an-tish-uhs."
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm walking through the old part of town at night, I get really anticious, like I can almost feel the people who built these streets watching us scroll on our phones; Reading that letter from my great-grandfather made me weirdly anticious about how he'd react to the way we live now; The movie wasn't scary, but the last scene where the camera panned over all those portraits made me so anticious I couldn't stop thinking about it afterward.

Definition: moment a conversation becomes real and alive, when a spark of trust shorts out the delicate circuits you keep insulated under layers of irony, momentarily grounding the static emotional charge you've built up through decades of friction with the world.
Etymology: In firefighting, aflashoveris when all the flammable material in an area combusts all at once.
Example Sentences: We were just trading small talk on the train when there was this sudden flashover and we ended up sharing really personal stuff; You could feel a kind of flashover in the room right after she admitted she was scared too; That podcast episode didn't grab me at first, but there's a real flashover about halfway through when the host opens up about his own mistakes.

Definition: curiosity about the impact you've had on the lives of the people you know, wondering which of your harmless actions or long-forgotten words might have altered the plot of their stories in ways you'll never get to see.
Etymology: Japanese 私 (watashi), I + 足跡 (ashiato), footprint. Pronounced "wah-tah-shee-ah-toh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes late at night I get hit with this weird Watashiato and start wondering about people I haven't talked to in years; That text you sent him before his interview gave him such a confidence boost—total Watashiato moment, even if you'll never know it; Watching my old students graduate fills me with Watashiato, thinking about all the tiny classroom moments that might've nudged them in one direction or another.

Definition: an innocuous touch by someone just doing their job—a barber, yoga instructor, or friendly waitress—that you find more meaningful than you'd like to admit; a feeling of connection so stupefyingly simple it makes you wonder if aspiring novelists would be better off just offering people a hug.
Etymology: In sports,incidental contactis a glancing touch that doesn't rise to the level of a foul. Acontact highis when you feel the effects of a drug vicariously.
Example Sentences: I swear I only keep going back to that coffee shop for the Incidental Contact High I get when the barista brushes my hand passing the latte; After months of working from home, that quick adjustment from the trainer at the gym hit me with such an Incidental Contact High I had to sit down and breathe; It's ridiculous how a two-second Incidental Contact High from the dentist's assistant fixing my bib felt more comforting than half my dates this year.

Definition: a moment that felt innocuous at the time but ended up marking a diversion into a strange new era of your life—a chance meeting you'd think back on for years, a harmless comment that sparked an ongoing feud, an idle musing that would come to define your entire career—a monumental shift secretly buried among the tiny imperceptible differences between one ordinary day and the next.
Etymology: In video compression, akey framedefines major changes in a scene. Most frames in compressed video arein-betweens, marking subtle incremental changes, but key frames depict a whole new scene. This technique allows you to move forward without stopping to buffer, even if it makes it harder to rewind.
Example Sentences: I always think of that awkward coffee with my old boss as the keyframe that pushed me to finally start my own business; Looking back, that random tweet I fired off at midnight was the keyframe for everything that happened with my career afterward; When my therapist asked what I'd consider the keyframe of the last decade, I immediately pictured that quiet train ride when I decided to move abroad

Definition: wish that people could suspend their civility and indulge the physical side of each other first—sniffing each other's hair like dogs, staring unabashedly at interesting faces, reveling in a beautiful voice like a song on the radio.
Etymology: Lithuanianžvėris, wild beast + Latinvērissimus, the truest, the realest. Pronounced "zvair-iz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Honestly, sometimes I think a little Zverism at parties would make introductions way less awkward; Her latest novel is soaked in Zverism, you can practically feel the characters circling each other like they're in a silent dance; He talks about Zverism like it's some lost art of being human, and I'm not sure if I'm intrigued or terrified.

Definition: sensing the judgment of your future self looking over your shoulder—chuckling at your well-laid plans or clutching their pearls at the risky move you're about to make—which leaves you faintly wary of their opinion, even though you know they'd take your place in a heartbeat.
Etymology: Fromfuture(the grammatical tense) +tense.
Example Sentences: Every time I hover over the confirm purchase" button for plane tickets

Definition: shock of meeting back up with someone and learning that your mental image of them had fallen wildly out of date—having grown up or gotten old, fallen apart or pulled themselves together—which shakes your faith in the accuracy of the social puppet show that runs continuously inside your head.
Etymology: Fromlook back+taken aback, taken by surprise.
Example Sentences: I ran into my old college roommate at the grocery store yesterday and the lookaback hit so hard I almost didn't recognize him; Every high school reunion is just three hours of pure lookaback for me, which is why I usually skip them; Scrolling through her photos online didn't prepare me for the real-life lookaback when she walked into the café looking like a completely different person.

Definition: age at which you become older than your parents were when you were born, which signals that your stage of the race has already begun, having spent years coasting in their slipstream as they tackled the mountain stages of life, leaving you strong, energetic, and deeply mortified by their loud yellow jerseys.
Etymology: Fromlap, one full circuit around a course +gap year, a regenerative break between adjacent stages of life. In the Tour de France, the cyclist with the lowest time receives a ceremonial yellow jersey and the right to start the next stage.
Example Sentences: I hit my Lap Year last month and suddenly started freaking out about retirement savings and regular health checkups; My brother's Lap Year is coming up, so we're planning a low-key family dinner where we can roast our parents a bit; She wrote this beautiful essay about her Lap Year and how it changed the way she talks to her mom about getting older.

Definition: afraid that you've been mentally deranged all your life and everybody around you knows, but none of them mention it to you directly because they feel it's not their place.
Etymology: Frommaunder, to mumble indistinctly +maugre, in spite of, notwithstanding. Pronounced "maw-gree."
Example Sentences: Sometimes, when everyone at the party went quiet at once, she'd get this sudden maugry feeling and just want to leave; I get a bit maugry whenever my friends exchange those weird glances and then change the subject; He laughed it off, but you could tell the late-night conversation about sanity had left him completely maugry the next morning.

Definition: tendency to give up trying to talk about an experience because people are unable to relate to it—whether through envy or pity or mere foreignness—which allows it to drift away from the rest of your story, until it feels out of place, almost mythical, wandering restlessly in the fog, no longer even looking for a place to land.
Etymology: Latinexulans, exile, wanderer, derived from the Latin name of the Wandering Albatross,diomedea exulans, who spend most of their life in flight, rarely landing, going hours without even flapping their wings. The albatross is a symbol of good luck, a curse, and a burden, and sometimes all three at once. Pronounced "ek-suh-lan-sis."
Example Sentences: I could see the exulansis setting in as soon as they changed the subject, so I just laughed it off and let the story die; After a few awkward attempts to explain what that year abroad was really like, I hit full exulansis and just told them it was fine"; She writes around that whole period of her life

Definition: frustration with how long it takes to get to know someone—spending the first few weeks chatting in their psychological entryway, with each subsequent conversation like entering a different anteroom, each a little closer to the center of the house—wishing instead that you could start there and work your way out, exchanging your deepest secrets first, before easing into casualness, until you've built up enough mystery over the years to ask them where they're from and what they do for a living.
Etymology: In Ancient Roman architecture, anandronitisis a hallway connecting the front part of the house with a complex inner atrium. One quirk of Roman houses is that all the rooms in the front have Greek names, but all the back rooms are in Latin—as if your outer self and your inner self are speaking in completely different languages. Pronounced "ad-roh-nahy-tis."
Example Sentences: I've got such adronitis with this new guy I'm dating—I just want to skip the small talk and actually know him; Her adronitis was obvious; after two coffees she was already asking me about my childhood fears

Definition: astonished to think back on the bizarre sequence of accidents that brought you to where you are today—as if you'd spent years bouncing down a Plinko pegboard, passing through a million harmless decision points, any one of which might've changed everything—which makes your long and winding path feel fated from the start, yet so unlikely as to be virtually impossible.
Etymology: Swedisheftersom, because.
Example Sentences: I always get this wave of aftersome when I think about how a missed bus led me to meet my business partner; Sitting at our kids' recital tonight, my sister and I were in full aftersome mode, tracing every weird little choice that got our families here; Talking with my grandfather about his life, you could see the aftersome in his eyes as he listed all the tiny moments that somehow added up to us.

Definition: beginning to suspect that you're living in a bizarre alternate reality, as if you had stumbled into a shimmering "What if?" thought bubble that somehow kept going, episode after episode.
Etymology: Afteroff, the state of being not quite normal or sane +offsides, a sports offense in which you find yourself on the wrong side at the wrong moment +tides, the normal ebb and flow of time.
Example Sentences: Time-Memory; Familiar-Unfamiliar; Imagination-Vision

Definition: a condition in which you have an active social life but very few close friends—people who you can trust, who you can be yourself with, who can help flush out the weird psychological toxins that tend to accumulate over time—which can eventually progress into a state of acute social malnutrition, where even if you devour an entire buffet of chitchat, you'll still feel pangs of hunger.
Etymology: Frenchmal, ache +de coucou, of the cuckoo bird.Coucouis also a French colloquialism for "Hey there!"Mal de coucouis a riff on the termmal de caribou, also known asrabbit starvation, in which you can starve to death even with unlimited access to lean meats like rabbit and caribou, after eating an excess of protein and not enough fat. Pronounced "mal duh koo-koo."
Example Sentences: Faces in a Crowd

Definition: longing to wander off your career track in pursuit of a simple life—tending a small farm in a forest clearing, keeping a lighthouse on a secluded atoll, or becoming a shepherd in the mountains—which is just the kind of hypnotic diversion that allows your thoughts to make a break for it and wander back to their cubicles in the city.
Etymology: GermanStadtzentrum, "city center" + Pennsylvania GermanRumspringa, "hopping around." Rumspringa is a putative tradition in which Amish teens dip their toes in modernity for a while before choosing whether to commit to the traditional way of life. Pronounced "truhm-spring-guh."
Example Sentences: Desire-Longing; Space-Solitude

Definition: a recurring thought that only seems to strike you late at night—an overdue task, a nagging guilt, a looming future—which you sometimes manage to forget for weeks, only to feel it land on your shoulder once again, quietly building a nest.
Etymology: Nighthawksis a famous painting by Edward Hopper, depicting a lonely corner diner late at night. In logging, anighthawkis a metal ball that slid up and down a riverboat's flagpole, to aid pilots in navigation.
Example Sentences: That old Nighthawk about never calling my grandfather back hit me again at 2 a.m., and I just lay there staring at the ceiling; Lately my Nighthawk has been this fear that I'm wasting my twenties, and it always shows up right when I'm about to fall asleep; I thought I'd finally moved on, but the Nighthawk swooped back in last night, reminding me of that email I've been avoiding for months.

Definition: weird loneliness of antiquated fads and memes and one-hit wonders, which tried so hard to capture their own era that they inadvertently became embedded in it.
Etymology: Italianaffogato, drowned. Pronounced "ah-fuh-gat-yuh."
Example Sentences: Every time that old ringtone plays on the bus, I get this wave of Affogatia that's hard to shake; Scrolling through my high school Facebook photos is pure Affogatia, like I'm visiting a museum of my own cringe; That playlist you made of 2000s hits is dangerous—I put it on while cleaning and suddenly I'm drowning in Affogatia instead of getting anything done.

Definition: frustration of being unable to fly, unable to stretch out your arms and vault into the air, having finally shrugged off the burden of your own weight, which you've been carrying your entire life without a second thought.
Etymology: Lakotamahpiohanzi, "a shadow caused by a cloud." Pronounced "mah-pee-oh-han-zee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time I watch birds migrating over the lake at sunset, that old Mahpiohanzia hits me harder than I expect; On the plane ride home, staring out at the clouds, I felt this weird mix of calm and Mahpiohanzia I couldn't quite put into words; She laughed about how her childhood drawings were all just different versions of her escaping her Mahpiohanzia in increasingly ridiculous superhero costumes.

Definition: an excuse you come up with to rationalize a disappointing outcome— telling yourself you weren't in the mood for that sold-out show anyway, that your safety school is actually a better fit, that your dream job might have been a bit too stressful.
Etymology: From the phrase "Well, I... um...," which typically precedes such an excuse. Pronounced "wel-ee- uhm."
Example Sentences: Koinophobia

Definition: ambient feeling of being a human being; a baseline mood that everyone feels intensely every moment of their lives, but can never pin down because they have nothing else to compare it to.
Etymology: Sanskritmanusyá, human being. Pronounced "muh-noo-zhuh" or "muh-noo-zee-uh."
Example Sentences: Kadang pas sendirian di kamar, gue cuma diem dan ngerasain Manusia itu kuat banget, sampai susah dijelasin; Waktu kita ngobrol semalaman di kafe itu, ada momen hening yang bikin Manusia kerasa beda, kayak lebih berat tapi juga hangat; Ada hari-hari tertentu di mana Manusia tiba-tiba nyentak, bikin lo sadar banget sama diri sendiri dan hidup lo sekarang

Definition: weird hollowness of trying to imagine the distant future—struggling to place it in any sort of context you'd find relatable but straining to believe it could feel all that different from the world around you.
Etymology: A word that looks liketomorrowfrom a distance but is actually something else that you can't really explain. Occasionally nuclear engineers try to work out how to warn future generations to stay away from radioactive waste sites, where it won't be safe to dig for ten thousand years. There are many challenges: stainless steel signs will eventually rust away, etchings in granite will be buffed clean by sandstorms, huge menacing earthworks shrouded in vegetation. Any words or symbols we leave behind will surely have lost their meaning by then, the Gregorian calendar replaced five times over, erasing any sense of when AD 12000 was supposed to be. It makes you wonder: If it seems impossible to pass a message beyond our own little neighborhood in time, impossible even to warn our descendants not to dig into poisoned ground, what relationship do we have to them? Pronounced "tohr-noh-mawf."
Example Sentences: I always get this wave of Tornomov when people ask where I see myself in 30 years; Last night we stayed up talking about AI, climate change, and all that Tornomov stuff until 3 a.m.; That movie hit me with such intense Tornomov during the final scene where the characters are old and looking back on everything

Definition: maddening sense that the world is too complex to even begin to understand, that whenever you try to answer even the most trivial question, it quickly tangles into a thicket of complications and melts into a quicksand of nuance, leaving you flailing for something solid to hold on to, struggling to come up with anything you could say that is definitively 100 percent true.
Etymology: Fromachene, the fruit that contains the seed of a flowering plant, which is often confused for the seed itself. Whenever you think you've arrived at the heart of something, it only ends up hidden away inside some other more complicated structure. Pronounced "uh-kee-nee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time I try to follow the news these days, I just end up drowning in pure Achenia and close the tabs; Lately my journal entries have turned into long rambles about this weird Achenia I feel whenever I think too hard about politics or ethics; When he started spiraling into Achenia during the meeting, I suggested we just pick a simple working assumption and move forward from there

Definition: intimidated by the awareness that you're in the present moment, right now, inhabiting the single fleeting second that exists, feeling like a surfer riding a cresting wave across an infinite sea, desperate to keep your balance, but unsure whether to lean forward or lean back.
Etymology: Frompresent, the moment at hand +tense, in a state of nervous strain.
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm lying in bed at night, the present tense hits me so hard I have to put on a podcast just to distract myself; During my panic attack, it wasn't the future that scared me, it was that overwhelming rush of present tense that made everything feel too bright and too close; After the accident, he said he lived in a constant present tense, like every second was teetering on the edge of something huge and unknown

Definition: to look around in a state of mild astonishment that your life is somehow still going, as if a part of you had just assumed that your allotment of days would've been used up by now, standing there like a player at a slot machine, perpetually surprised that your winnings continue to trickle out, but not sure what you're supposed to do now.
Etymology: Fromto be+to loiter, to hang around someplace with no particular agenda. Pronounced "bih-loi-ter."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I'll just stand in the kitchen at midnight, Beloiter for a minute, and then suddenly remember I still have emails to answer; Every birthday lately turns into this weird mix of gratitude and Beloiter, like I'm waiting for someone to tell me the game is over; After the accident, he'd Beloiter in the mirror every morning before work, as if double-checking that he was really still here.

Definition: fear that your partner is changing in ways you don't understand, even though they might be changes for the better, because it forces you to wonder whether your relationship needs a few careful nudges to fall back into balance, or perhaps is still as stable as ever, but involves a person who no longer exists.
Etymology: Middle Englishfere, partner, companion +heresy, deviation from established practices or beliefs. Pronounced "fer-uh-see."
Example Sentences: I've been feeling this weird Feresy lately, like I'm proud of how much he's grown but also strangely out of sync with him; When she started talking about changing careers and moving abroad, my Feresy kicked in harder than I expected; We finally had a long talk about my Feresy instead of pretending I was totally fine with all the changes he's been making.

Definition: disillusionment of revisiting a pop-culture touchstone of your youth and finding that it hasn't aged well at all—having to confront its cringey dialogue, hand-puppet characterization, and wildly implausible plotting—which only makes you wonder what else in your mental fridge is past its expiration date.
Etymology: Appalachian English (dialect)blinked, soured milk +back, in the past.
Example Sentences: I tried rewatching that old fantasy show last night and had a total Blinkback halfway through the first episode; Every time my friends talk about doing a nostalgic movie marathon, I warn them about the risk of a massive Blinkback; That sequel was clearly made just to cash in on our Blinkback for the original series, but it somehow made the memories even worse

Definition: unease of knowing how quickly your circumstances could change on you—that no matter how carefully you shape your life into what you want it to be, the whole thing could be overturned in an instant, with little more than a single word, a single step, a phone call out of the blue, and by the end of next week you might already be looking back on this morning as if it were a million years ago, a poignant last hurrah of normal life.
Etymology: Latincrāstinō diē, tomorrow +praxis, the process of turning theory into reality. Pronounced "krak-sis."
Example Sentences: I've been feeling this weird Craxis all week, like something's about to pull the rug out from under me; When the doctor said she needed to talk about the results

Definition: a quiet jolt of recognition that it's time to become a better version of yourself, sensing that all the strategies that brought you this far are no longer working—that it's not enough anymore to be cute or nice or righteous or tough—as if you've now entered a new phase in the game of life, moving forward with a completely different token.
Etymology: Dutchpuntstuk, railway frog, which is the part of a railway switch where two rails intersect. Sometimes you can feel a little kick when your train passes over it, as if the world is trying to signal you're missing a turn, having traveled too far on the same old track.
Example Sentences: I had a real Punt Kick moment after that breakup, like the universe was politely telling me to level up instead of just wallowing; Lately I've been getting these little Punt Kicks at work, nudging me to stop coasting and actually take on projects that scare me; Turning 30 was a total Punt Kick for me, the kind that makes you rethink who you've been and who you're trying to become.

Definition: fear that learning the name of something—a bird, a constellation, an attractive stranger—will somehow ruin it, inadvertently transforming a lucky discovery into a conceptual husk pinned in a glass case, leaving one less mystery fluttering around in the universe.
Etymology: Frenchaimer, to love +nom, name. A palindrome. Pronounced "eym-uh-nohm-ee-uh."
Example Sentences: I almost googled what that wildflower was called, but my Aimonomia kicked in and I just walked away instead; She laughed and said her Aimonomia is why she never asks for people's names at parties, even if she really clicks with them; The documentary was fascinating, but it totally shattered my Aimonomia about the night sky—I can't look at those constellations the same way anymore.

Definition: primal longing for a home village to return to, a place that no longer exists, if it ever did; the fantasy of finding your way back home before nightfall, hustling to bring in the cattle before the rains come; picturing a cluster of lanterns glowing on the edge of a tangled wood, hearing the rattle and hiss of meals cooking over a communal fire, finding your place in a crowded longhouse made of clay-packed thatch, where you'd sit and listen to the voices of four generations layered into a canon, telling stories of a time when people could still melt into a collective personality and weren't just floating around alone.
Etymology: Fromheart+moor, to tie a boat to an anchor. Pronounced "hahrt-moor."
Example Sentences: Every time that song comes on during a long drive, it hits me with this wave of Heartmoor that I can't quite shake; Lately my dreams have been full of Heartmoor, like I'm walking through a village I've never seen but somehow recognize; She just stared into the fire for a while and said, I think what I'm feeling is Heartmoor

Definition: primal trance of watching a campfire in the dark.
Etymology: GermanFunken, spark +Zwangsvorstellung, obsession. Pronounced "foon-ken-tsvang-svohr-stel- oong."
Example Sentences: Gestern am See sind wir alle total in diese Funkenzwangsvorstellung abgerutscht und haben stundenlang nichts anderes gemacht; jedes Mal, wenn ich gestresst bin, wünsche ich mir einfach eine ordentliche Funkenzwangsvorstellung am Lagerfeuer; er meinte nur lachend, dass meine angebliche Meditation" eigentlich bloß eine ausgewachsene Funkenzwangsvorstellung war."

Definition: a random image that becomes lodged deep in your brain—maybe washed there by a dream, or smuggled inside a book, or planted during a casual conversation—which then grows into a wild and impractical vision that keeps scrambling around in your head, itching for a chance to leap headlong into reality.
Etymology: From the title character of the 1982 filmFitzcarraldo, directed by Werner Herzog, about a man who is overcome by the thought of hearing Caruso's operatic tenor echoing through the Peruvian jungle; to fund this effort he hires local people to pull a steamship over a mountain, a feat that was done for real for the film's production. Pronounced "fits-kuh-rawl-doh."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk past that old theater, my Fitzcarraldo kicks back in and I start daydreaming about turning it into a tiny art-house cinema; She laughed and said, That sounds like a total Fitzcarraldo

Definition: half-remembered acquaintances you knew years ago, who you might have forgotten completely if someone hadn't happened to mention them again—friends of friends, people you once shared classes with, people you heard stories about, who you didn't know well but who still made up the fabric of your intense little community—making you wonder who else might be out there somewhere, only just remembering that you exist.
Etymology: Spanishlos olvidados, "the forgotten"—but not completely. Pronounced "lohs vee-dah-dohs."
Example Sentences: I ran into one of Los Vidados at the grocery store, and it took me a full minute to place where I knew her from; Every time I scroll through old yearbook photos, a few more of Los Vidados come rushing back to me; After the reunion, we all ended up texting about Los Vidados and wondering what they're doing with their lives now

Definition: phenomenon in which you catch your reflection in the mirror and get the sense that you're peering into the eyes of a stranger, as if you're looking at a police sketch of your own face aged forward twenty years, which would imply that the real you is out there somewhere, wandering the streets of your old neighborhood, still at large.
Etymology: In horticulture,whip graftingis when you fuse the top of one plant to the bottom of another. In psychology,the Capgras delusionis the conviction that a loved one has been replaced by an identical-looking imposter.
Example Sentences: I had a full-on episode of The Whipgraft Delusion last night brushing my teeth, and it totally threw off my whole evening; Every time I'm sleep-deprived, The Whipgraft Delusion hits me so hard I have to step away from the mirror for a bit; My therapist actually knew what The Whipgraft Delusion was, which was a relief, because I thought I was the only one who experienced that kind of thing

Definition: fear that your deepest connections with people are ultimately pretty shallow, that although your relationships feel congenial in the moment, an audit of your life would reveal a smattering of low-interest holdings and uninvested windfall profits, which will indicate you were never really at risk of joy, sacrifice, or loss.
Etymology: Greek αναχλός (anachlós), loosely held together + -φοβία (-phobía), fear. May also appear asapomakrysmenophobia. Pronounced "nok-luh-foh-bee-uh."
Example Sentences: Lately my Nachlophobia has been flaring up, so even small talk at parties leaves me weirdly hollow afterward; My therapist says the Nachlophobia isn't about other people so much as it is about how I show up in my own relationships; When I scrolled through my contacts and realized how few people I'd actually call in a crisis, the Nachlophobia hit me harder than ever.

Definition: a sense of loneliness looking up at the night sky, feeling like a castaway marooned in the middle of the ocean, whose currents are steadily carrying off all other castaways—entire worlds and stars whose only remnant is a scrap of light they flung overboard centuries ago, a message in a bottle that's only just now washing up on our shores.
Etymology: Fromstar, a luminous dot in the cloudless sky +-lorn, sorely missing. Pronounced "stahr-lawrn."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I get a little starlorn on those long walks home, when the city finally goes quiet and the sky feels way too big; The movie was gorgeous, but that last scene—where she's just standing on the rooftop, completely starlorn—hit a little too close to home; I wasn't sad exactly, just sort of starlorn, lying on the hood of the car and watching the constellations drift by in silence.

Definition: wish that you could've enjoyed a dry run of your life—muddling through once quickly, then going back to do it all over again, this time for real.
Etymology: Spanisharroyo, a dried-up streambed waiting for a storm, literally a "dry run." Pronounced "uh-roi-uh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes that late-night Arroia hits me so hard I just lie there replaying every choice I've ever made; I get this weird wave of Arroia whenever I finish a big project, like I want to rewind and do the whole thing again but better; Talking to my grandpa about his life always fills me with Arroia, like I'm getting a sneak preview I'll never actually get to use.

Definition: longing for a sense of certainty in a relationship; wishing there were some way to know ahead of time whether this is the person you're going to wake up next to for twenty thousand mornings in a row, instead of having to count them out one by one, quietly hoping your streak continues.
Etymology: Mandarin 确 认 (quèrèn), confirmation. Twenty thousand days is roughly fifty-five years. Pronounced "kweh-ruh-nuhs."
Example Sentences: I've been feeling so querinous lately that even a sweet text from him just makes me overthink everything; She admitted in therapy that her most querinous moments hit right before she falls asleep, when she starts imagining all the possible futures; Watching them exchange vows, I wasn't jealous of the wedding itself, just weirdly querinous about whether I'll ever feel that sure about someone.

Definition: fear that your connections with people will keep dwindling as you get older; that one by one, you'll all go flying off the merry-go-round in wildly different directions, sailing through various classes and jobs and interests, ultimately landing in far-flung neighborhoods where you'll hunker down with your families plus a handful of confidants you see a few times a year, perpetually reassuring each other, "We should keep in touch."
Etymology: Greek φύγω (fýgo), I leave + -φοβία (-phobía), fear. Compare the Greek φυγόκεντρος (fygókentros), centrifuge. Pronounced "fahy-goh-foh-bee-uh."
Example Sentences: Connection-Relation; Time-Memory

Definition: feeling a vague longing for some sort of monarch to look down upon us from a high and distant castle, which you'd imagine would pacify the squabbling chaos of civic life and drastically narrow the range of choices and issues you have to think about, finally freeing you up from bearing the microscopic fraction of a crown that forever hangs over your head.
Etymology: From the chess move of castling, which is when a rook rushes to protect the king, nearly swapping places with him.
