Example Sentences: Every time the news cycle gets overwhelming, I get this weird rookish mood where I half-wish some distant crown would just sort it all out; She laughed at my rookish daydreams and reminded me I'd probably be the first one to complain about having a king; Lately there's been a rookish tone in his essays, like he's tired of pretending we're all eager to carry the weight of our own tiny kingdoms.

Definition: a chilling hint of distance that creeps slowly into a relationship— beginning to notice them laugh a little less, look away a little more, explain away their mood like it's no longer your business—as if you're watching them fall out of love right in front of you, gradually and painfully, like a hole in the radiator that leaves your house a little colder with every passing day, whose only clue is a slow, unnerving drip—drip —drip.
Etymology: Middle Englishriven, to rend, to cleave apart. Pronounced "riv-uh-ner."
Example Sentences: I could feel the rivener setting in weeks before we finally broke up, but I didn't know how to bring it up without sounding paranoid; Lately there's been this weird rivener between my sister and me, like we're both quietly backing away from the conversation; When he told me everything was fine" in that flat voice

Definition: unsettling awareness that the rest of the world happily carries on in your absence, that although things only ever seem to change when you check back in for an update, they're unwilling to wait for you, and undergo massive shifts while your back is turned—your mother getting older, your old friends becoming different people, your hometown losing some of the hallmarks that made it feel like home.
Etymology: Middle Englishmithen, to be hidden away. Pronounced "mith-uhn-nis."
Example Sentences: Every time I visit my hometown and see another shop boarded up, that old Mithenness hits me all over again; Scrolling through everyone's life updates after a week offline just gives me this weird wave of Mithenness I can't quite shake; I had a sudden flash of Mithenness at the reunion, realizing how much everyone had changed while I was busy with my own life

Definition: sense that the future is arriving ahead of schedule, that all those years with fanciful names are bursting from their hypothetical cages into the arena of the present, furiously bucking your grip while you slip around in your saddle, with one hand reaching for the reins, the other waving up high like a schoolkid who finally knows the answer to the question.
Etymology: Italiana domani, until tomorrow +mania. Pronounced "ad-uh-mey-nee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time I see another Class of 2035" hoodie at the mall

Definition: total set of human beings alive at any given time, a group that nudges slightly forward whenever a new baby is born or the world's oldest person dies, and turns over completely every hundred years or so; a random assemblage of billions of contemporaries who you feel an odd sense of connection to, because whatever problems we might face right now, we're all facing them simultaneously.
Etymology: Fromnow, the present moment +-lings, inhabitants of.‍
Example Sentences: Sometimes I think the Nowlings forget how strange it is that we're all sharing this exact sliver of history together; The documentary tried to capture what life feels like for the Nowlings, but it barely scratched the surface; When the power went out across half the city, there was this weird sense of solidarity, like the Nowlings had all paused and taken a breath at the same time.

Definition: regret at having cracked the code of something, which leaves you wishing you could forget the pattern—longing to unsee an optical illusion, to unlearn the formula behind your favorite songs and shows and movies, or re-canonize a role model you made the mistake of meeting in person.
Etymology: Tahitianiriti, to translate +iriti, to be convulsed. Pronounced "ih-ri-shun."
Example Sentences: I felt this weird irrition after my film class ruined every plot twist for me, like I'll never be surprised by a movie again; Ever since I started producing my own tracks, I've had this low-key irrition listening to pop hits because I can hear every trick they're using; Meeting my favorite author at that signing filled me with irrition—now I can't read their books without thinking about how awkward that conversation was.

Definition: humbled by how readily you place your life into the hands of random strangers, often without a second thought—trusting a restaurant to check its expiration dates, trusting a construction crew not to cheap out on materials, trusting thousands of other drivers to stay in their lane —people who you may never meet but whose well-being you're deeply invested in, whether you know it or not.
Etymology: Danishtillid, trust. Pronounced "til-id."
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm on a plane and look around at all the other passengers, I'm overwhelmed by this weird sense of tillid toward the pilots and crew; Standing on that swaying suspension bridge, I felt this intense tillid in the engineers who designed it, even though I'll never know their names; Ordering street food in a country where I don't speak the language always brings out my tillid in the kindness and competence of total strangers.

Definition: an imaginary conversation with an old photo of yourself, in which you might offer them a word of advice—to banish your worries, soak it all in, or shape up before it's too late—or maybe just ask them if they thought you had done justice to the life they built for you.
Etymology: Fromdaguerreotype, a form of early portrait photography +dialogue. Pronounced "duh-gair-uh- lawg."
Example Sentences: I had a little Daguerreologue with my 18-year-old self last night after finding that old prom photo in a drawer; Every time I scroll back through my college pictures, I end up slipping into a full-on Daguerreologue and lose track of time; On rough days, my therapist actually encourages a kind of structured Daguerreologue as a way to reconnect with who I used to be and what I wanted back then

Definition: feeling of loss that you never had a chance to meet a certain person before they died, which compels you to try to get to know them anyway, gathering snapshots and stories to build out a sketch of who they were, learning them like a character in a novel, which makes them feel all the more alive even though you've already skipped ahead and read the last page.
Etymology: Latinappretiare, to appraise +ad pressum, after. Pronounced "ap-ree-es."
Example Sentences: I didn't expect that old documentary to hit me so hard, but it left me with this intense appriesse for the director I'd never even heard of before; Ever since my grandfather passed, my mom's been deep in appriesse, digging through letters and photo albums like she's piecing together a mystery; That podcast episode about the poet sent me into full-on appriesse last night—I was up till 3 a.m. reading their journals and interviews online

Definition: dispiriting awareness that the twists and turns of your life feel new and profound but are not unique—marked by the same coming-of-age struggles as millions of others, the same career setbacks, the same family strife, the same learning curve of parenting—which makes even your toughest challenges feel harmless and predictable, just another remake of the same old story.
Etymology: A riff onblues standards, the catalog of the most popular songs in the blues genre, which is itself famous for chord progressions that cycle through variations on a theme.
Example Sentences: Every time I scroll through those relatable" life memes

Definition: practice of making offhand comments that sound sarcastic but are actually sincere and deeply felt.
Etymology: Fromskidding, going farther than intended out of inertia +kidding, joking around.
Example Sentences: I could tell she wasn't skidding this time—she really meant every word of that compliment; You're skidding again, aren't you? I can never tell if you're joking or actually being sweet; His speech sounded like he was just skidding his way through it, but you could see how much he cared.

Definition: quiet poignance of your own responsibility for someone, with a mix of pride and fear and love and humility—feeling a baby fall asleep on your chest, or driving at night surrounded by loved ones fast asleep, who trust you implicitly with their lives—a responsibility that wasn't talked about or assigned to you, it was assumed to be yours without question.
Etymology: Fromhub, the central part of the wheel that bears the weight +jubilance. Pronounced "hyoo-buh- luhns."
Example Sentences: When I looked in the rearview mirror and saw all three kids knocked out in their car seats, that wave of Hubilance hit me so hard I had to turn the music down and just focus on the road; There was this quiet Hubilance in the way he adjusted the blanket around his dad's shoulders, like it was the most natural thing in the world; I didn't really feel the Hubilance of being an older sister until Mom left the house and all the little ones instinctively turned to me without saying a word.

Definition: melodramatic thrill of unrequited love; the longing to pine for someone you can never have, wallowing in devotion to some impossible person who could give your life meaning by their very absence.
Etymology: Portugueseamor, love +ânsia, craving. Pronounced "ah-moh-ran-see-uh."
Example Sentences: Ever since college, he's chased that same Amoransia he felt for his first crush, like he doesn't know how to like someone who might actually like him back; Sometimes I wonder if I'm genuinely into her or if it's just Amoransia making everything feel more intense than it really is; You say you want a healthy relationship, but all your playlists and late-night texts scream pure Amoransia.

Definition: haunting sense of mystery infused into certain random details that beckons you to wonder how it ended up here at this point in time—marveling at a patch of white on a dog's chest, a bubble trapped in an old window, a glimpse of Saturn's rings shivering in a telescope lens—knowing that behind the thing itself is a long chain of causes and effects that veers off into the shadows of prehistory, anchored somewhere near the dawn of time, even though the end result is somehow right there in front of you, shimmering in place.
Etymology: Indonesianeksis, to exist, to be. Pronounced "ek-sis."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I get this weird ecsis when I'm staring at old family photos, like each scratch on the picture is hiding a whole story; Walking home last night, the ecsis hit me out of nowhere when I saw a single lit window in that abandoned building; She paused mid-sentence, ecsis washing over her as she traced the chipped edge of the teacup with her thumb.

Definition: smallest measurable unit of human connection, typically exchanged between passing strangers—a warm smile, a sympathetic nod, a shared laugh about some odd coincidence—moments that are fleeting and random but still contain powerful emotional nutrients that can alleviate the symptoms of feeling alone.
Etymology: Ancient Greek ξένος (xénos), alien, stranger. Pronounced "zee-noh."
Example Sentences: I was having such a rough day on the train, but that quick Xeno with the woman sitting across from me actually made me feel seen; Sometimes all it takes is a tiny Xeno with the barista or the person holding the door to remind me I'm not completely alone in this city; We didn't even exchange names, but that little Xeno outside the clinic waiting room stuck with me for the rest of the week.

Definition: fear that your society is breaking apart into factions that have nothing left in common with each other—each defending their own set of values, referring to their own cult figures, speaking in their own untranslatable language.
Etymology: Fromanaphase, the stage in cell division when sister chromatids are pulled apart to opposite sides of the cell +aphasia, the inability to comprehend or formulate language due to brain dysfunction. Pronounced "an-uh-fey-zhah."
Example Sentences: Lately my anaphasia's been so bad I can't even read the news without feeling like everyone's living in parallel universes; He calls it just politics

Definition: awareness of the infinitesimal role you play in shaping your own society—knowing that whenever you smile at a stranger, pronounce a word a certain way, laugh at a certain joke, or choose the slightly shinier apple, you are unwittingly helping to construct the world in which you live—a role both vanishingly small but also somehow daunting, making it that much harder to complain about the traffic, knowing that you are traffic.
Etymology: Irisheisceacht, exception. Pronounced "ahy-shuh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm people-watching on the train, I get this weird rush of Eisce and suddenly feel hyper-aware of every tiny choice I'm making; After that conversation about how trends start, I couldn't shake the Eisce I felt just from deciding which meme to share; I was standing in line at the grocery store, picking out yogurt, and this wave of Eisce hit me so hard I almost put everything back and walked out.

Definition: self-contained pajama universe shared by two people on a long weekend morning, withdrawing from the world and letting the hours slow to a crawl, coming as close as they'll ever get to pausing the flow of time, even as they know it'll eventually rush back in all the faster.
Etymology: Frommorn, morning +den, a comfortable room that affords private time. Pronounced "mawrn-duhn."
Example Sentences: We've got the whole weekend to ourselves—can we just stay in a Mornden and ignore our phones until Sunday night?; Every time work gets overwhelming, I think back to that snowy January Mornden we spent in the cabin and it instantly calms me down; They were supposed to meet us for brunch, but apparently they're still in full Mornden mode and refusing to get out of bed.

Definition: trying to improve yourself without anyone else knowing about it, afraid that they'll think it's silly or grandiose or unnecessary, or that they'll end up calling too much attention to your efforts, transforming a casual tweak into a flashy rebranding campaign.
Etymology: Armenian բարելավվել (barelavvel), to become better. Pronounced "bair-lev-uhl-ing."
Example Sentences: I've been bareleveling my coding skills at night so my coworkers don't start asking why I'm suddenly trying so hard"; Honestly

Definition: sadness that there's no way to convey a powerful memory to people who weren't there at the time—driving past your childhood home to show it to a friend, or pointing at a picture of a loved one you lost, only to realize that to them it's just another house, just another face.
Etymology: A contraction ofauld lang syne, which is Scots for "times long past"—fragments of which are still present inaulasy, but the meaning has been lost. Pronounced "awl-uh-see."
Example Sentences: Time-Memory; Beginnings-Endings; Desire-Longing

Definition: fear that this is ultimately as good as your life is ever going to get—that the ebb and flow of your fortunes is actually just now hitting its high-water mark, and soon enough you'll sense the tide of life slowly begin to recede.
Etymology: Fromever+nevertheless. Pronounced "ev-er-thuh-les."
Example Sentences: I had a great time at the wedding, but on the drive home I was hit by this weird evertheless that made me oddly quiet; Sometimes when I'm laughing with my friends late at night, an evertheless sneaks in and I start wondering if this is the last time life will feel this simple; He finally got the promotion he'd been chasing for years, but instead of pure joy, there was this heavy evertheless sitting in the back of his mind

Definition: curiosity about the real flesh-and-blood people behind internet usernames, whose flamboyant uniqueness suggests that when our parents were searching our nameless faces looking for hints of who we would become, they really should have considered Mr. Cookieface, Unicornpuncher, Dutchess Von Whatever, or Wookiegasm.
Etymology: In digital graphics,anti-aliasingis a technique to smooth the appearance of jagged pixels in low-resolution images.
Example Sentences: Every time I scroll through the comments, I get this weird Anti Aliasing and start imagining what GoblinDad420" is like in real life; Last night we spent an hour in Discord just indulging our Anti Aliasing about all the people in our raid group; My Anti Aliasing kicked in hard when I realized I've known "PixelPrincess" for five years and still have no idea what her actual name is."

Definition: act of trying to keep an amazing discovery to yourself, fighting the urge to shout about it from the rooftops because you're afraid that it'll end up being diluted and distorted, and will no longer have been created just for you.
Etymology: In the Tolkien legendarium,Trahaldis the true name of Sméagol (Gollum), a creature who spent centuries hiding in dark wet caves, enthralled in jealous worship of his precious enchanted ring.
Example Sentences: I've been Trueholding this little indie podcast for months because I don't want it blowing up on TikTok; There's a fine line between sharing your joy and slipping into full-on Trueholding, but sometimes I just want to keep my favorite spots to myself; She accused me of Trueholding when I refused to post about that tiny bookstore I found on my trip, but I kind of like that almost no one knows it's there

Definition: awareness that although a certain experience may strike you as utterly unremarkable, it might be having a profound effect on other people nearby, who will remember every detail for the rest of their lives—having inspired the birth of a phobia, a fetish, a lifelong relationship, or a lifelong career.
Etymology: In poker and blackjack, the ace card can be valued either low or high; it's up to the player to decide. Every day is an ace, which might end up being valuable or worthless, forgettable or unforgettable, depending on who's playing and what else they're holding in their hand.
Example Sentences: I had a real Heart Of Aces moment at that random coffee shop conversation, and only years later did I realize how much it changed my brother's life; Sometimes I'll be halfway through a boring meeting and suddenly get hit with Heart Of Aces, wondering if someone here is going to remember this forever; Watching the kids at the museum, I couldn't shake the Heart Of Aces feeling that this dull Tuesday field trip might secretly be a turning point for one of them.

Definition: mysteriously compelled to wave to passing strangers on a country road, a mountain path, or a remote stretch of water.
Etymology: Fromhail, to greet +bound, being obliged.
Example Sentences: Every time we drive through those little coastal towns, my hailbound sister ends up waving at half the people we pass; I didn't realize how hailbound I'd become until my hand went up automatically when that lone kayaker paddled by; He jokes that being hailbound makes road trips take twice as long, because he has to slow down to acknowledge everyone on the trail.

Definition: a resurgent emotion that you hadn't felt in years, that you might have forgotten about completely if your emotional playlist hadn't accidentally been left on shuffle.
Etymology: In music, adeep cutis a lesser-known track that only an artist's true fans or completists might appreciate.
Example Sentences: Every time I hear that song, it hits me with this Deep Gut I thought I'd grown out of years ago; Seeing her name pop up on my phone out of nowhere just triggered a Deep Gut I wasn't ready for; That movie didn't just make me cry, it stirred up some old Deep Gut I didn't even realize was still there

Definition: mildly disappointed that you'll never be able to attend your own memorial service; frustrated that you could spend your entire life trying to build some sort of legacy to leave behind, but just barely miss your chance to catch a glimpse of what that legacy might be.
Etymology: GermanEffekt, effect +less. As he was dying at age forty, Franz Kafka instructed his friend Max Brod to burn all his literary works upon his death, but Brod famously defied the request and published them to worldwide acclaim. At the time, Max Brod had been a household name, a celebrated author whose first novel was hailed as a masterpiece. Meanwhile, Kafka had spent his life walking the streets of Prague as a complete unknown, and died without ever suspecting that his hometown would soon become synonymous with his name. The world had been unequivocal in its judgment of the two writers, but posterity soon overturned the verdict.
Example Sentences: Every time I see those videos of people's surprise tributes, I get weirdly eftless, like I'm missing out on my own finale; Sitting alone on the train after my grandfather's funeral, I wasn't exactly sad anymore, just this quiet, lingering eftless that I'd never really know how people would talk about me when I'm gone; I get a little eftless whenever I finish a big project at work, imagining the speeches they'd give if I just vanished the next day.

Definition: a painful memory that you look back upon with unexpected fondness, even though you remember having dreaded it at the time; a tough experience that has since been overridden by the pride of having endured it, the camaraderie of those you shared it with, or the satisfaction of having a good story to tell.
Etymology: Fromhark back, a command spoken to hunting dogs to retrace their course so they can pick up a lost scent. Pronounced "hahrk."
Example Sentences: Honestly, that whole semester felt awful while we were in it, but now it's kind of a Harke we all joke about when we get together; I didn't realize that night would turn into such a Harke until years later, when we started telling the story at every reunion; Finishing that project was brutal, but it's become my favorite Harke to bring up in job interviews.

Definition: feeling uneasy when socializing with odd combinations of friends and family, or friends and colleagues, or colleagues and family—mixing a medley of ingredients that don't typically go together, which risks either watering down your identity into gray mush, or accidentally triggering some sort of explosion.
Etymology: Frommotley, comprising incongruous elements +headed. Pronounced "mot-l-hed-id."
Example Sentences: I always get a bit mottleheaded when my coworkers and my college friends end up at the same party; Just thinking about my parents meeting my D&D group makes me so mottleheaded I want to cancel the whole dinner; By the time my boss started chatting with my ex at the wedding, I was too mottleheaded to enjoy the rest of the night.

Definition: wondering if you could slip away from an event or group conversation without anyone noticing your absence.
Etymology: Old Norsedár, benumbed +forgone, to have already left or abstained. Pronounced "dohr-gon."
Example Sentences: I was halfway through the reception when the Dorgone hit me and I started eyeing the side door; During that long staff meeting, the only thing keeping me awake was my growing Dorgone; You could see the Dorgone on her face the moment the small talk turned to quarterly reports again.

Definition: a pulse of shame you feel even though you've done nothing wrong— passing a police car while under the speed limit, being carded after legally ordering a drink, or exiting a store without buying anything.
Etymology: Fromfool's gold+guilt. Also known as areverse Alford plea, whereby you plead innocent to all charges but want the judge to know that you feel kinda guilty anyway.
Example Sentences: Every time I walk out of a store without buying anything, that Fools Guilt hits me and I feel like the security cameras are all zooming in; I got this weird Fools Guilt when the cop car pulled up behind me, even though I knew I wasn't speeding; She laughed and said the Fools Guilt was real when the bartender double-checked her ID, even though she's thirty-two.

Definition: sheepish casual vibe between two people who've shared an emotional farewell but then unexpectedly have a little extra time together, wordlessly agreeing to pretend that they've already moved on.
Etymology: Fromgood-bye+do-over.
Example Sentences: We already did the whole teary goodbye at the airport, so when her flight got delayed and she wandered back over, it was just pure Bye Over energy; We had this awkward little Bye Over moment in the parking lot, both of us scrolling our phones like we hadn't just hugged it out five minutes earlier; After the big farewell at the train station, running into him again at the snack shop turned into this goofy Bye Over where we just talked about chips like nothing had happened.

Definition: sadness that you'll never be able to know how history will turn out, that you'll dutifully pass on the joke of being alive without ever learning the punch line, which may not suit your sense of humor anyway and will probably involve how many people it takes to change a lightbulb.
Etymology: Fromellipsis, a marker of a continuation that you don't get to see. Pronounced "ih-lip-siz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been feeling this weird ellipsism whenever I read about climate change and politics, like I'm stuck in the middle chapters of a book I'll never finish; My grandpa used to talk about his own ellipsism during the space race, wondering what kind of future he'd never get to see; That movie hit me hard, not because of the ending, but because it stirred up my ellipsism about where our world is actually heading after the credits roll.

Definition: feeling lonely in a crowd; drifting along in a sea of anonymous faces but unable to communicate with or confide in any of them.
Etymology: Middle Englishleed, countrymen, compatriots +lonesome.
Example Sentences: I always get this weird Ledsome vibe at big conferences, like I'm surrounded by people but not really there with them; By the end of the wedding reception I was so Ledsome I just slipped outside to sit on the steps and check my phone; She texted me from the festival saying she felt totally Ledsome and asked if I could call just so she'd hear a familiar voice.

Definition: a person who has no idea where their home is, or was, or when they might have left it—which leaves their emotional compass free to swing around wildly as they move from place to place, pulling them everywhere and nowhere all at once, making it that much harder to navigate.
Etymology: Middle Englishnaur, nowhere +begone, surrounded. Pronounced "nair-bi-gawn."
Example Sentences: I ran into that musician from the hostel again—total Neer Be Gone vibes, living out of a backpack and already planning to leave town tomorrow; My brother's been a bit of a Neer Be Gone since college, bouncing between cities and jobs without ever really settling; The main character in that novel is such a Neer Be Gone, drifting from country to country and relationship to relationship like nothing ever quite sticks.

Definition: a kind of mistake you wouldn't take back even if you could; the reluctance to disown a broken relationship or agonizing experience that has since become part of who you are, and trying to disown it would mean you're trying to live some other life.
Etymology: Latinin-, not +errata, mistakes in a printed work. Pronounced "in-eh-rah-tuh."
Example Sentences: Honestly, that whole mess with my old business partner is pure inerrata at this point—I wouldn't rewrite it even if I had the chance; She called the relationship her greatest inerrata, something that still hurt but also shaped every decision she makes now; When I look back on college, all the chaos, bad choices, and heartbreak just feel like inerrata woven into who I am today

Definition: a conversational hint that you have something personal to say on the subject but don't go any further—an emphatic nod, a half-told anecdote, an enigmatic "I know the feeling"—which you place into conversations like those little flags that warn diggers of something buried underground: an unexploded bomb, a sacred burial ground, or a high-voltage cable that secretly powers your house.
Etymology: Fromsemaphore, a communication method used at sea, in which sailors stand on deck and move flags into certain positions to convey simple messages. Pronounced "sem-uh-fawr-iz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Gnossienne

Definition: pang of loneliness you feel the day after an intensely social event, as the glow of voices and laughter fades into a somber quiet.
Etymology: Fromafterglow+gloom.
Example Sentences: I always get hit with this weird aftergloom on Mondays after a big weekend with friends; She warned me the aftergloom would kick in once her family flew back home and the house went quiet; I tried to fight the aftergloom by keeping busy, but the silence after the reunion just made it worse.

Definition: eerie tranquility of fast-moving clouds, who pass through your patch of sky like a drifter stepping into your entryway to warm up for a minute, ruffling the ice from his beard before he nods his gratitude and turns back into the air.
Etymology: Japanese ふ浪者 (furōsha), vagrant, vagabond. Onomatopoeic to the sound of a sudden gust of wind. Pronounced "fuh-roh-shuh."
Example Sentences: I got stuck staring out the train window, totally lost in the furosha above the fields; There's this strange kind of furosha right before the storm hits, and it always makes me feel weirdly calm; Last night's hike was nothing special, but the furosha over the ridge made it feel like we were walking through a painting

Definition: afraid to relax your body and drift off to sleep because you can't help but notice how much it rhymes with death—lying flat on your back, your hands clumped on your chest, trying to force yourself to let go of consciousness, knowing you'll almost certainly find your grip again but unsure exactly how that happens.
Etymology: Armenian քնել (k'nel), sleep +knell, a ringing announcement of a death. Pronounced "nel-ish."
Example Sentences: Every time I lie down at night, I get this weird knellish feeling that keeps me staring at the ceiling; She laughed and said my late-night texts always sound a little knellish, like I'm half joking and half spiraling; After that horror movie, the whole mood in the room turned knellish, and nobody wanted to be the first to turn off the lights.

Definition: fear that everyone around the world is pretty much the same—that despite our local quirks, we were all mass-produced in the same factory, built outward from the same generic homunculus, preinstalled with the same tribal compulsions and character defects—which would leave you out of options if you ever want to reinvent yourself, or seek out a better society on the other side of the globe.
Etymology: A riff on thetragedy of the commons, which is a situation where individual users acting in their own self-interest end up harming the common good, usually by depletion or pollution of resources.
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm scrolling through social media and every vacation photo looks identical, I get this weird Treachery Of The Common feeling and just want to disappear into the woods; He talks about Treachery Of The Common a lot in his writing, like this low-key dread that no matter where you move, people will be running on the same basic script; After a few months of backpacking, the Treachery Of The Common hit me hard, like, Wow

Definition: desire to hold on to time as it passes, like trying to keep your grip on a rock in the middle of a river, feeling the weight of the current against your chest while your elders float on downstream, calling over the roar of the rapids, "Just let go—it's okay—let go."
Etymology: Fromanchorage, a port at which ships may anchor. Pronounced "ang-ker-ij."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I get this weird sense of anchorage when I'm looking through old family photos, like I'm trying to freeze everyone exactly as they were; Lately I've been catching myself scrolling through my camera roll every night, and I know it's just anchorage, but I can't help wanting to hold on to every little moment; When my grandparents talk about how quickly life goes by and tell me not to worry so much, it clashes with this anchorage I feel whenever I see my parents getting older.

Definition: a moment of sudden involvement in a stranger's personal life— rushing over to break up a fight, helping a teary-eyed parent struggling with a stroller, righting someone's bike after a bad fall—that shatters the invisible glass box that usually surrounds us in public, the one we prefer to pretend is impenetrable, which somehow renders us unable to speak.
Etymology: Fromcovalence, literally "shared strength." In chemistry, acovalent bonddescribes the force that holds two atoms together upon sharing a loose outer shell of electron pairs. Pronounced "ko-vey-luhnt bond."
Example Sentences: Connection-Relation; Familiar-Unfamiliar; Shift-Movement

Definition: wistful feeling of looking around a gathering of loved ones, all too aware that even though the room is filled with warmth and laughter now, it won't always be this way—that the coming years will steadily break people away into their own families, or see them pass away one by one, until there comes a time when you'll look back and try to imagine what it felt like to have everyone together in the same place.
Etymology: Fromether, an intoxicating compound that evaporates very quickly +togetherness. Pronounced "eth-er-nis."
Example Sentences: I was hit with this sudden etherness at Thanksgiving, just watching my grandparents laugh with the little kids at the end of the table; Sometimes old photos trigger that same etherness, like you can almost step back into the noise and chaos that's gone; As the night wound down and people started grabbing their coats, a kind of quiet etherness settled over me, even though I was still smiling and joking with everyone.

Definition: disorientation of stepping outside a movie theater into unexpected darkness—a twinge of jet lag after letting your mind escape to some other world for a while, only to be thrown abruptly back into reality.
Etymology: Italianrialto, a theater district +oscuro, dark, obscure. Comparechiaroscuro, which describes a quality of visual art that emphasizes the contrast between deep shade and bright light. Pronounced "ree-al-toh-skyoor-oh."
Example Sentences: I had this weird Rialtoscuro walking out of the cinema last night, even though it was only six in the evening; Every time we binge-watch an entire season and then step outside, I get hit with that same Rialtoscuro feeling; She laughed and said the Rialtoscuro was worse after that sci‑fi marathon than after an actual red‑eye flight

Definition: feeling small and alone while walking the streets of an unfamiliar city, swept along in the commercial bustle of asphalt and neon, dwarfed by impenetrable monoliths looming high overhead, brushed aside by pulses of traffic carrying on their daily business, with nobody willing to look you in the eye except for the posters encrusted on subway walls, each of them pitching at someone other than you.
Etymology: Fromwen, an enormously congested city that swells like a cyst +bane, an affliction or poison.
Example Sentences: I always get this weird wave of Wenbane whenever I step out of the train at Shinjuku and just follow the crowd without really knowing where I'm going; By the third day of the conference, the Wenbane had hit me so hard that I just went back to my hotel early and ordered room service instead of exploring; She said the Wenbane didn't really fade until she'd found a tiny café where the owner remembered her name and her usual order.

Definition: a conversation in which everyone is talking but nobody is listening— instead merely overlaying words like a spoken game of Scrabble, each player borrowing bits of others' anecdotes to build out their own, until we reach a point when we all run out of things to say.
Etymology: Fromanecdote, a short and often amusing account of real-life events +synecdoche, a figure of speech in which a part stands for the whole. Pronounced "uh-nek-doh-kee."
Example Sentences: Our weekly team meetings always devolve into pure anecdoche, and we leave without deciding anything; By the time Thanksgiving dinner hit the two-hour mark, the table had turned into a loud anecdoche that gave me a headache; I bailed on the group chat because it was just an endless anecdoche and I couldn't get a word in that anyone actually heard

Definition: to wander through the grounds of a cemetery, glancing over the gravestones as if you were people-watching the dead, imagining all the things they must have seen and the lives they might have led, trying to conjure up an entire biography from a handful of words and dates etched in granite, with barely more than a single dash to cover the unimaginable vastness of their experience.
Etymology: Fromover, finished and done with +pine, to yearn or grieve for something. Compare the flowering perennialorpine, also calledautumn joyorlive-forevers, which is often found in open sunny areas of cemeteries. Pronounced "awr-pahyn."
Example Sentences: We used to oerpine through that old hillside cemetery after school, making up stories about the people buried there; On quiet Sunday mornings, my grandpa would take me to oerpine among the graves and talk about how every stone held a universe; When I'm feeling stuck with my writing, I go out to oerpine in the churchyard until a character finally starts talking to me.

Definition: feeling wistful upon brushing past a person you once shared a life with—noticing the same touch on the arm, seeing the same smile, hearing the same laugh you used to adore—suddenly all too aware that it's no longer for you, and no longer carries the meaning it once did.
Etymology: Old Englishsithen, since then +natheless, not less by that. Pronounced "sih-thuh-les."
Example Sentences: I thought I was fine until I saw them together at the party, and that old, sitheless feeling hit me out of nowhere; Walking past our favorite café this morning, I caught a glimpse of him through the window and went completely sitheless for the rest of the day; She tried to laugh it off after the meeting, but you could tell from her eyes she'd gone a bit sitheless when she ran into her ex in the hallway

Definition: meditative atmosphere of being alone in a bathroom, sequestered inside your own little isolation booth, enjoying a moment backstage from the razzle-dazzle of public life.
Etymology: Latinpax, a period of peace +latrina, toilet. ComparePax RomanaorPax Americana; sometimes the solace of bathroom stalls can feel just as profound as the protection of empires. Pronounced "paks luh-tree-nah."
Example Sentences: Honestly, my favorite part of visiting my parents is locking the door, running the shower, and just sinking into some pure Pax Latrina for ten minutes; After that chaotic wedding reception, I hid in a stall for a bit of Pax Latrina before going back out to dance; I wake up early mostly so I can have my coffee and enjoy a little Pax Latrina before my roommates start banging on the door.

Definition: an activity that you've adored since you were a kid—riding bikes, reading books, taking pictures, cooking food—whose enjoyment dissolves on contact with hardcore fanatics' ferocious obsession with technique.
Etymology: Fromamuse-bouche, a bite-size appetizer intended to tantalize the palate +douche. Pronounced "ah-mooz-doosh."
Example Sentences: I used to love sketching, but after joining that hyper-competitive art Discord, the whole thing turned into an Amuse Douche for me; Every time I try to get back into home brewing, I remember how that club meeting turned my chill hobby into a total Amuse Douche; Her blog started out as a fun cooking diary, but once the comments filled up with purists nitpicking everything, it slowly became an Amuse Douche.

Definition: struck by the poignant strangeness of other people's homes, which smell and feel so different than your own—seeing the details of their private living space, noticing their little daily rituals, the way they've arranged their things, the framed photos of people you'll never know.
Etymology: Fromelse, other +wise, with reference to.
Example Sentences: I always get a bit elsewise when I'm staying at someone's house for the first time, just wandering around their kitchen and taking it all in; Sitting on their couch, flipping through their photo albums, I felt suddenly elsewise, like I'd stepped sideways into a parallel version of what a home" can be; The place was cozy and familiar to them

Definition: brooding delirium of being sick, which makes time slow to a trickle and turns even the most pathetic of tasks into monumental struggles, until the act of lifting your head from the pillow feels like trying to climb a mountain, wondering if you'll ever find your way back again, or even catch your breath.
Etymology: A riff on the French toastsanté. Literally, "un-health!" Pronounced "day-sahn-tey."
Example Sentences: I was stuck in bed with the flu all week, totally lost in that Desante, and it felt like the days were never going to end; Even after the fever broke, a bit of that Desante lingered, and just answering emails felt like wading through wet cement; When she texted that she was in full-on Desante, I knew better than to push her about the project deadline.

Definition: tendency for social networks to magnify unexpected personality traits of people you know, a consequence of compressing someone's raw persona into a low-res digital format, which can randomly brighten their outer glow, sharpen their comic edges, darken their shadows, or add motion blur to a stationary life.
Etymology: In digital photo processing,unsharp maskis a filter that combines the original negative with a blurred positive image. The resulting image may look sharper but is actually a less accurate interpretation of the subject.
Example Sentences: I always thought Mark was super serious, but on Instagram The Unsharp Mask makes him look like this chaotic meme lord.; After a few months off Twitter, coming back felt weird—The Unsharp Mask on everyone's profiles was so strong I barely recognized how my friends were presenting themselves.; It's strange meeting online friends in person and realizing how much The Unsharp Mask had distorted my sense of who they were.

Definition: feeling hollowed out by excessive exposure to modern technology, which is so fast and stimulating that it makes everything else feel drab and messy by comparison—as if you'd unwittingly developed a psychological allergy to chaos, which leaves you feeling punchy and lonely and numb, even though your life might be as peaceful and predictable as it's ever been.
Etymology: Fromiron sick, a nautical term for when an old ship's iron nails become rusted out, allowing seepage of seawater through the wooden hull.
Example Sentences: I've been feeling totally ironsick lately, like even a quiet weekend offline just makes me restless and weirdly numb; Sometimes I can tell he's ironsick when he scrolls for hours and then says everything in real life feels too slow" now; After that month of nonstop virtual meetings and hyper-edited videos

Definition: disorienting feeling of meeting back up with an old friend and realizing that you've become different people on divergent paths—that even though they're standing right in front of you, the person you once knew isn't really there anymore.
Etymology: After the part of a VCR that reads the signal on a videotape.
Example Sentences: Every time I run into Jake at the grocery store, I get that Spinning Playback Head feeling and don't quite know what to say anymore; Sitting across from her at the café, the Spinning Playback Head hit me so hard I kept reaching for stories that didn't fit either of us now; I thought it'd just be a fun reunion, but halfway through dinner the Spinning Playback Head kicked in and I realized we were basically strangers.

Definition: longing to disappear completely; to melt into a crowd and become invisible, so you can take in the world without having to take part in it—free to wander through conversations without ever leaving footprints, free to dive deep into things without worrying about making a splash.
Etymology: Fromslip, to move or fly away in secret +fast, fortified against attack.
Example Sentences: Sometimes on the subway after a long day, I just go full Slipfast and let everyone's conversations wash over me; At parties I don't know how to talk to people, so I usually find a corner, Slipfast for an hour, and then sneak out; Traveling alone was perfect—I could Slipfast through cities, museums, and cafés without anyone expecting anything from me

Definition: unsettling awareness of your own heartbeat, whose tenuous muscular throbbing feels less like a metronome than a nervous ditty your heart is tapping to itself, as if to casually remind the outside world, I'm here, I'm here, I'm here.
Etymology: In music,tempo rubato, "stolen time," is a slight speeding up and slowing down of the tempo of a piece, borrowing time from one measure then paying it back later. Pronounced "roo-bah-toh-sis."
Example Sentences: Senses-Perception; Identity-Personality

Definition: reservoir of all possible opportunities still available to you at this point in your life—all the countries you still have the energy to explore, the careers you still have the courage to pursue, the skills you still have time to develop, the relationships you still have the heart to make—like a pail of water you carry around in your head, which starts off feeling like an overwhelming burden but steadily draws down as you get older, splashing gallons over the side every time you take a step.
Etymology: Fromthe till, a shopkeeper's register filled with unspent change +until.
Example Sentences: I know the breakup sucks, but try to think about The Til and everything you still haven't even tried yet; When I turned thirty, I made a list of what was still in The Til for me—places to live, projects to start, people to meet—and it actually made me feel excited instead of old; Lately I've been saying no to stuff that doesn't matter, because I don't want to waste what's left in The Til on things I'll forget in a week.

Definition: a feeling of quiet amazement that you exist at all; a sense of gratitude that you were even born in the first place, that you somehow emerged alive and breathing despite all odds, having won an unbroken streak of reproductive lotteries that stretches all the way back to the beginning of life itself.
Etymology: Spanishsuerte, luck +fuerza, force. Pronounced "soo-wair-zuh."
Example Sentences: Sometimes I'll just sit on the balcony at sunrise and feel this wave of Suerza wash over me for no reason at all; After the accident, waking up in the hospital, the first thing that hit me wasn't fear, it was this intense Suerza I couldn't even put into words; On my worst days, I go for a long walk, put on some music, and try to reconnect with that sense of Suerza I used to feel so easily as a kid

Definition: a caricature of yourself that went out of date years ago, though nobody around you seems to have noticed.
Etymology: Italiantipi fissi, "fixed types," the stock characters in commedia dell'arte masked improvisational theater. Pronounced "tip-uh-fis."
Example Sentences: Identity-Personality; Shift-Movement

Definition: an unexpected burst of good news that only makes you skeptical, believing that every sudden rise in your fortunes must inevitably be accompanied by an impending fall, which leaves you feeling uneasy at the end of a really good day, waiting around for the punch line.
Etymology: Middle Englishwinne, joy +wawe, woe. Comparewilliwaw, a sudden blast of wind descending from the mountains to the sea. Pronounced "win-uh-waw."
Example Sentences: I got a bonus at work and a surprise refund check on the same day, and all I could think was, Okay

Definition: a relationship or friendship that you can't get out of your head, which you thought had faded long ago but is still somehow alive and unfinished, like an abandoned campsite whose smoldering embers still have the power to start a forest fire.
Etymology: Fromheart+earworm, a catchy piece of music that compulsively loops inside your head.
Example Sentences: I ran into Maya at the coffee shop yesterday, and all that old heartworm came rushing back before I could even say hello; Sometimes I wonder if that late-night text I never answered is why the heartworm still sticks with me; He swears he's over her, but every time her name comes up you can see the heartworm flicker in his eyes again.

Definition: awed at the impact someone has had on your life, feeling intimidated by how profoundly they helped shape your identity, having served as a ghostwriter of a work that nevertheless only appears under your name.
Etymology: Fromthrapped, drawn tight, as with nautical ropes +rapt, carried away with emotion.
Example Sentences: I always get a little thrapt when I think about how different my life would be if I hadn't met her in college; He laughed it off, but you could tell he was totally thrapt sitting across from the mentor who basically set his whole career in motion; Finishing the book left me weirdly thrapt, knowing how much of it came from someone else's voice even though only my name is on the cover.

Definition: a state of exhaustion with continually being told what you want to hear, whether by marketers pandering to you or acquaintances afraid of causing offense; the longing for someone to have the heart to finally call you out on your bullshit, challenge your long-held assumptions, and push you to become a better person—which would be a far deeper kindness than trying to live and let live.
Etymology: Froman-, against +echoes. Pronounced "an-uh-koh-sis."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been feeling this weird anechosis, like everyone's just nodding along instead of actually telling me when I'm wrong; That whole retreat felt like anechosis to me—so many people agreeing with each other just to stay positive" that nothing real ever got said; If you notice me slipping into old patterns

Definition: lulling sound of a running dishwasher, whose steady maternal shushing somehow puts you completely at peace with not having circumnavigated anything solo.
Etymology: Latinplata, plate +rasa, blank or scraped clean. Pronounced "pla-tuhrah-suh."
Example Sentences: Every Sunday afternoon I curl up on the couch with a book and let the Plata Rasa wash over me from the kitchen; When we got back from that chaotic trip, I just stood in the dark, listening to the Plata Rasa and finally felt my shoulders drop; She laughed and said she didn't need a meditation app as long as she had a working dishwasher and her nightly dose of Plata Rasa

Definition: moment you wake up from an immersive dream and have to abruptly recalibrate to the real world—unquitting your job, falling right back out of love, reburying your lost loved ones.
Etymology: In American football, thedrop kickis when a player drops the ball and kicks it as it bounces off the ground, used as a method of restarting play.
Example Sentences: I hate The Kick Drop after a weekend nap, when I open my eyes and realize none of what just happened was real; Last night's dream was so vivid that The Kick Drop this morning left me staring at the ceiling for ten minutes; She said The Kick Drop hits hardest on Mondays, when your dream self's life feels better organized than your actual one.

Definition: state of being so familiar with someone that you can be in a room with them without thinking, without holding anything back, or without having to say a word—to the extent that you have to remind yourself that they're a different being entirely, that brushing hair away from their eyes won't help you see any better.
Etymology: Southwest English dialectsuent, easy, peaceful, smooth. Pronounced "soo-ent-ey."
Example Sentences: I didn't realize how much Suente we had until we sat through that whole flight in silence and it never felt awkward; Sometimes I have to pull back a little, because the Suente between us makes me forget where I end and you begin; After a few years of living together, our Suente got so strong that my mom joked we share the same brain now

Definition: finding a person so attractive it actually kinda pisses you off.
Etymology: Fromhanker, to pine after something +canker sore, which gets worse the more you're aware of it.
Example Sentences: Every time he walks into the room in that leather jacket, I get this ridiculous hanker sore and have to look away; I didn't expect to feel that hanker sore over some random actor in a commercial, but here we are; She was trying to focus on the meeting, but the new guy's smile gave her a serious hanker sore the entire time.

Definition: someone whose mood is perpetually out of sync with everyone else around them, prone to feelings of naptime panic, heart-to-heart snark, or dance club pensiveness.
Etymology: Fromemotional+dox, not conforming to expected norms. Pronounced "ee-moh-doks."
Example Sentences: You could totally tell he was an Emodox at the party, laughing during the sad songs and zoning out when everyone else was hyped; My sister's such an Emodox that she started getting all reflective and moody right in the middle of my birthday dinner; The group chat is chaos, but leave it to an Emodox like Jamie to drop a deep, broody message just as we're all sending memes.

Definition: bittersweetness of having arrived here in the future, finally learning the answers to how things turned out but being unable to tell your past self.
Etymology: Frenchénouer, to pluck defective bits from a stretch of cloth +dénouement, the final part of a story, in which all the threads of the plot are drawn together and everything is explained. Pronounced "ey-noo-mahn."
Example Sentences: I was hit with this intense enouement at my college reunion, seeing where everyone ended up after all those late-night study sessions and wild plans; Sitting in my new office on the first day, I felt a strange enouement thinking about how stressed I used to be over getting this exact job; Watching my kids play in the backyard, there's this quiet enouement that sneaks up on me, remembering how scared I was that I'd never have a family of my own.

Definition: a glint of goodness you notice in someone that you wouldn't expect, which is often only detectable by sloshing them back and forth in your mind until everything dark and gray and common falls away, leaving something shining at the bottom of the pan—a rare element hidden deep in the bedrock, that must've been washed there by a storm somewhere upstream.
Etymology: Frenchla gaudière, from Latingaudere, to find joy. Pronounced "lah gou-dee-yair."
Example Sentences: I didn't really like him at first, but then I caught this little La Gaudiere in the way he talked about his sister, and it completely changed how I saw him; Sometimes it takes a long night of overthinking someone before their La Gaudiere finally shows up, like a tiny light you almost missed; Even after everything she did, there was still a bit of La Gaudiere in her messages that made it impossible for me to write her off completely.

Definition: sorrow of imagining the wealth of knowledge forever lost to history—knowing we'll never hear the language of the Etruscans, the battle cry of the Sea Peoples, or the burial chants of the Neanderthals; that we'll never read any more than a fragment of the works of Blake, Sappho, Aristotle, or Jesus; or enjoy the untold treasures of so many burned libraries and forgotten oral traditions and unrecorded songs—any of which might have made up the cornerstone of the canon, that we'd all be able to quote by heart and couldn't imagine living without.
Etymology: A contraction ofKergeulen Islands. Roughly equidistant between Australia, Antarctica, and Madagascar, they are the only visible remnant of the Kergeulen microcontinent, which was submerged some twenty million years ago. Three times the size of Japan, it was once covered in dense conifer forests, with peaks reaching 2,000 meters above sea level, populated with strange and nameless fauna that must have called it home, before all traces were lost beneath the waves. Pronounced "kair-ahyl."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk through a museum's ancient history wing, I'm hit with this wave of Kerisl that's hard to shake; Lately my Kerisl's been flaring up whenever I think about all the stories that never got written down; That poem you sent me captured my Kerisl so perfectly I had to just sit there and stare at the wall for a few minutes

Definition: a hypothetical conversation that you compulsively play out in your head—a crisp analysis, a devastating comeback, a cathartic heart-to-heart—which serves as a kind of psychological batting cage that feels far more satisfying than the small-ball strategies of everyday life.
Etymology: Frenchjusqu'à, until. In baseball, "small ball" is a cautious offensive strategy devoted to getting on base via walks, bunts, and steals, forgoing the big home run moments that fans tend to enjoy. Pronounced "zhoos-ka."
Example Sentences: Between Living and Dreaming

Definition: a certain scent that has the power to sweep you back to childhood— the acrid funk of bug spray, the earthy sweetness of dead leaves on wet asphalt, the rebellious twang of gasoline fumes in the summer heat.
Etymology: Fromyewthor, a pungent scent +yewre, water-bearer. Pronounced "yoh-ree."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk past that old gas station, I get this hit of Yeorie that makes me think of long road trips with my parents; The rain started, and suddenly the whole playground smelled like pure Yeorie, and I was eight years old again; I bought a candle they said was inspired by Yeorie, but it didn't even come close to the real thing.

Definition: delirium of having spent all day in an aesthetic frame of mind— watching a beautiful movie, taking photos across the city, getting lost in an art museum—which infuses the world with an aura of meaning, until every crack in the wall becomes a commitment to naturalism, and every rainbow swirling in a puddle feels like a choice.
Etymology: Short forgo-between. In theatrical lighting, agobois a layer inserted into a lamp that shapes the pool of light that hits the stage. Pronounced "goh-boh."
Example Sentences: I was still in full-on gobo after leaving the gallery, like even the subway ads felt profound; That walk home in the rain put me into such a gobo that even the traffic lights looked perfectly choreographed; I love chasing that feeling of gobo, when the whole city suddenly seems like it's arranging itself just for you.

Definition: a musical flavor found in electric guitar solos that compels you to snarl, squint, and arch your spine like a yowling jungle cat.
Etymology: Onomatopoeic to the wail of an electric guitar. Pronounced "ow-yow-yuh."
Example Sentences: I swear the solo at 2:47 has the purest Aoyaoia I've heard in years; The new pedal I bought doesn't add much distortion, but it cranks the Aoyaoia way up; When she hit that last bend on stage, the whole crowd felt the Aoyaoia and just lost it.

Definition: phenomenon of observing your parents interact with people they grew up with, which reboots their personalities into youth mode, offering you a glimpse of the dreamers and rascals they used to be, before you came into the picture.
Etymology: Refers to Marty McFly, the protagonist ofBack to the Future, who travels back in time and interacts with his parents while they're still in their teens.
Example Sentences: Every time my mom visits her old college roommates, The Mcfly Effect kicks in and suddenly she's staying up past midnight laughing at dumb inside jokes; I swear The Mcfly Effect was in full force at that reunion—my super serious dad turned into this goofy, loud teenager I've never met before; My brother and I just sat on the couch watching The Mcfly Effect happen as our parents swapped stories with their high school friends and started talking like they were 17 again.

Definition: feeling that everything you do is always somehow wrong—that there's nothing you can eat that's actually healthy, nothing you can say that isn't problematic, no way to raise your kids that won't leave them traumatized—which makes you wonder if there's some obvious way forward that everybody can see but you, each of them leaning back in their chair and calling out helpfully, "Colder... colder... colder..."
Etymology: Frompar 0(par zero), a theoretical hole on a golf course in which it's already too late—no matter how well you hit the ball, you've already fallen behind. The circumflex on theâis a tiny symbol of someone trying for something then retreating. Compare the Spanishparo, a stoppage or a freezing-up. Pronounced "pahr-oh."
Example Sentences: Lately my Paro has been so bad that I second-guess every tiny decision, even what kind of cereal to buy; She texted me after the meeting, saying her Paro was flaring up because she felt like everything she'd said had come out wrong; When my Paro kicks in, I have to log off social media and call a friend who can remind me I'm not actually ruining everything.

Definition: point in your early adolescence when you realize that your parents are muddling through their lives the same as you; that many respectable adults are no less lost than you and your friends, no less petty and obsessive and insecure, which makes you wonder if there are no real adults, because such a thing never actually existed, except in bedtime stories.
Etymology: GermanKinder, children. Refers toKinder Surprise, a foil-wrapped chocolate egg that contains a small toy that's already broken into pieces. Pronounced "thuhkin-der ser-prahyz."
Example Sentences: I think The Kinder Surprise hit me the day I overheard my parents arguing about something as trivial as whose turn it was to take out the trash; My little brother is going through The Kinder Surprise right now, and it's weird watching him realize our mom doesn't have everything figured out; That breakup, plus moving out for college, kind of triggered The Kinder Surprise for me—I suddenly saw all the grown-ups in my life in a totally different light

Definition: exhausted by endless reviews and secondhand impressions; itching to stumble blindly into the world and make some mistakes, to wander around opening doors to restaurants and performances and movies you've never heard of, without the slightest idea of what to expect.
Etymology: Fromstar, a standard rating unit of reviews +stuck.
Example Sentences: I've been so star stuck lately that I ditched Yelp and just walked into the first tiny cafe I saw on the corner; After months of scrolling through movie ratings, we got totally star stuck and just bought tickets to the weirdest indie film on the marquee; She sounded kind of star stuck on the phone, like she just wanted to pick a random street and see where it took her instead of reading ten blogs about it first.

Definition: scattering of memories that your brain is actively forgetting at any given moment, erasing them one by one with no input from you and no knowledge that it's happening at all—which means that when you wake up in the morning, your past will feel imperceptibly altered, with no trace of what you ate last week, a party you attended ten years ago, or the first real conversation you had with your grandfather.
Etymology: Fromcull, to control the size of a herd by selectively killing some animals +away. Pronounced "kuhl-uh-weys."
Example Sentences: Sometimes, right before I fall asleep, I can almost feel the Cullaways starting to tug at the edges of the day; It's wild to think that a year from now tonight will probably just be part of the Cullaways, no matter how important it feels right now; Whenever I look at old photos and don't remember taking them, I wonder how many more moments are already lost to the Cullaways without me even noticing.

Definition: a moment of panic that you'll end up looking back on years of labor with little to show for it, that despite all the time you've spent gathering skills and connections and experiences, many of them will prove to have been worth almost nothing in the long run, redeemable for petty cash, a line on a résumé, a few compliments, or a handful of magic beans.
Etymology: Fromrout, a chaotic retreat +wash, a meager return on investment +outwash, the gravelly sediment left by water flowing from a melting glacier.
Example Sentences: Every time I scroll through LinkedIn and see everyone's promotions, I get hit with this wave of routwash that ruins my whole evening; I was in the middle of writing my thesis when a sudden routwash made me wonder if any of it would matter in ten years; We should probably schedule that career check-in you mentioned, because the routwash has been creeping in a lot more lately.

Definition: a sense of weariness with the same old problems that you've always had, the same boring issues and anxieties you've been gnawing on for decades, which makes you want to spit them out and dig up some fresher pain you might have buried in your mental backyard.
Etymology: Germanalt, old +Schmerz, pain. Pronounced "alt-shmerts."
Example Sentences: Lately the Altschmerz has been hitting hard, like I'm just exhausted by replaying the same worries every night; I thought therapy would help with the Altschmerz, but some days it just makes me more aware of how long I've been stuck with it; When the Altschmerz gets too loud, I throw myself into a new hobby just to drown out that tired old mental noise.

Definition: a humble pulse of gratification you feel when acting as a citizen— serving on a jury, standing in line at a polling place, taking part in a debate at a town meeting—where you can actually feel the gears of democracy turning ever so slightly, because you actually had a hand in it.
Etymology: Latingaudia, joys +civis, citizen. Pronounced "gou-dee-uhsiv-is."
Example Sentences: Every time I drop my ballot into the box, I get this little rush of Gaudia Civis that carries me through the rest of the day; Sitting in that crowded school gym for the town hall, I wasn't expecting much, but when they actually adopted our proposal, the Gaudia Civis was unreal; She joked that she only volunteers for the election board because she's addicted to that feeling of Gaudia Civis when the polls finally close and the results start coming in.

Definition: feeling a sense of loss upon finishing a good book, sensing the weight of the back cover locking away the lives of characters you've gotten to know so well.
Etymology: Fromlooseleaf, a removable sheet of paper +left, departed.
Example Sentences: I had such bad Looseleft after finishing that trilogy last night that I just lay there staring at the ceiling; She warned me the Looseleft would hit hard once I got to the epilogue, but I didn't expect to feel this empty; I'm already getting pre-Looseleft vibes and I'm only halfway through the book, so I'm trying to read it really slowly.

Definition: an itchy sense of dread when life feels just a hint too peaceful—when everyone seems to get along suspiciously well, with an eerie stillness that makes you want to brace for the inevitable collapse, or burn it down yourself.
Etymology: Fromharmony+paranoia. Pronounced "hahr-muh-noi-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time a family gathering goes by without a single argument, I get this weird Harmonoia and start wondering what disaster we're all subconsciously avoiding; Lately the office has been so quiet and agreeable that my Harmonoia is off the charts, like we're in the calm before some massive reorg; I was finally starting to relax in the new relationship, and then out of nowhere the Harmonoia kicked in and I kept waiting for something to go horribly wrong.

Definition: fear that you're little more than a product of your circumstances, that for all the thought you put into shaping your beliefs and behaviors and relationships, you're essentially a dog being trained by whatever stimuli you happen to encounter—reflexively drawn to whoever gives you reliable hits of pleasure, skeptical of ideas that make you feel powerless.
Etymology: From Jacques de Vaucanson, a French engineer who built a series of lifelike programmable machines (automata), including his masterpiece theDigesting Duck, which could flap its wings and quack, drink water, and digest bits of grain into simulated excrement. Pronounced "vaw-kuh- see."
Example Sentences: Sometimes that late-night Vaucasy hits me and I start questioning whether I actually chose my career or just followed the path of least resistance; After that breakup, he went through a whole phase of Vaucasy, wondering if he'd ever really loved her or just gotten used to the comfort; I get a twinge of Vaucasy whenever I catch myself changing my opinions just because someone I admire said something different.

Definition: a twinge of sadness that there's no frontier left, that as the last explorer trudged his armies toward the last blank spot on the map, he didn't suddenly turn for home, leaving one last island unexplored so we could set it aside as a strategic reserve of mystery.
Etymology: Latinlacuna, an unfilled space or hole + Spanishla cuna, cradle. Pronounced "lahkoo-nuh."
Example Sentences: Every time I watch old documentaries about the age of exploration, I get hit with this weird La Cuna feeling afterward; Standing on the crowded overlook, with every trail mapped and every viewpoint tagged on social media, she joked that the only thing we hadn't optimized yet was our La Cuna; His novel really leans into La Cuna, like the characters are haunted by this quiet longing for a blank space they'll never find

Definition: awareness that your partner perceives the relationship from a totally different angle than you—spending years looking at a different face across the table, listening for cues in a different voice—an odd reminder that no matter how much you have in common, you're still in love with different people.
Etymology: Dutchander, another person, someone else. Pronounced "an-der-uhns."
Example Sentences: I had this weird rush of Anderance last night when I realized the way you remember our first date is nothing like how I remember it; Sometimes the Anderance hits me when we're arguing and I can tell you're not just disagreeing, you're actually living in a different version of us"; After ten years together

Definition: afraid that the rest of your life is already laid out in front of you, that you're being swept inexorably along a series of predictable milestones—from school to graduation to career to marriage to kids to retirement to death—which makes you wish you could pull off to the side of the road for a little while, to stretch your legs and spread out the map so you can double-check that you're headed the right way.
Etymology: Middle Englishcauci, path or road +caustic, able to burn or corrode living tissue. Pronounced "kaw-sik."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been feeling really caucic, like everyone expects me to just follow the script without asking if it's what I actually want; She had a bit of a caucic meltdown at her desk after yet another meeting about five‑year plans and next steps"; Whenever my parents start talking about grandkids

Definition: a sincere emotion that seems to wither into mush as soon as you try to put it into words—like reeling in a shimmering beast from the deep only to watch it wriggle limply on the line, which makes you want to leave it down there, languishing unexpressed, where it'll grow dark and slender and weird, with ghostly blue eyes and long translucent teeth.
Etymology: Thesailfishis a species of fish noted for its violent power, its eponymous signaling fin, and its ability to change colors like a chameleon. It's also known as theboohoo.
Example Sentences: I had so much sayfish after the concert that I just hugged her instead of trying to talk about it; Sometimes I write letters I'll never send, just to bleed off a little sayfish without having to actually explain anything; You could see the sayfish in his eyes when he looked at his kids, even though he barely said a word.

Definition: vivid memories of a certain experience that you carry in your head for years until they're casually disputed by someone who remembers it very differently—correcting basic chronology, clarifying a misread gesture, or adding context you never knew—which makes you want to look again at all the images you've been using to piece together your worldview, wondering what details might've been hidden in shadow all this time, or washed out by your own naïveté.
Etymology: After documentary filmmaker Errol Morris, whose work often addresses the fallibility of memory and how little of reality can be captured in a photograph. Pronounced "em-uh-reez," likememories, but with a piece missing.
Example Sentences: Time-Memory; Complexity-Confusion; Fact-Fiction

Definition: maddening inability to understand the reasons why someone loves you—almost as if you're selling them a used car that you know has a ton of problems and requires daily tinkering just to get it to run normally, but no matter how much you try to warn them, they seem all the more eager to hop behind the wheel and see where this puppy can go.
Etymology: Latinimmerens, undeserving. Pronounced "ih-muhr-en-sis."
Example Sentences: Every time she looks at me like I hung the moon, I just sit there in pure Immerensis, wondering what on earth she sees; His songs are basically a diary of Immerensis, all these lyrics about not deserving the person who keeps choosing him; After therapy, the Immerensis didn't vanish, but at least he stopped trying to talk her out of loving him.

Definition: suddenly aware that you're more than halfway through a vacation or semester or other positive experience, noticeably closer to the end than the beginning, as if someone had flipped your mental hourglass overnight, turning a rush of fun surprises into a trickle of last hurrahs.
Etymology: Norwegian Bokmålhalvveis, halfway.
Example Sentences: I woke up today and realized I'm already halfwise through the trip, and now every little moment feels weirdly precious; She got all sentimental and halfwise during midterms, like the semester was already slipping through her fingers; We were laughing at dinner when it suddenly hit me halfwise, and I started planning what I wanted to squeeze into the last few days.

Definition: inexplicably moved by predictable and well-worn sentiments, even if they're trite or obvious or being broadcast blindly to the masses.
Etymology: From the middle name of Mr. Fred McFeely Rogers. You deserve to be happy. Your feelings matter. You are loved. You are enough.
Example Sentences: I always get a little Mcfeely during those cheesy holiday commercials, even though I know they're totally manipulative; Don't judge me, but that speech at the end of the movie had me full-on Mcfeely, tears and all; She rolled her eyes at the cliché proposal, but you could tell she was secretly feeling pretty Mcfeely about it.

Definition: ethereal feeling of looking down at the world through an airplane window, able to catch a glimpse of far-flung places you'd never see in person, free to let your mind wander, trying to imagine what they must feel like down on the ground—the closest you'll ever get to an objective point of view.
Etymology: Latinvolare, to fly +solander, a book-shaped box for storing maps. Pronounced "voh-land-uhr."
Example Sentences: Every time I fly home at night and see the tiny lights scattered below, that weird Volander hits me so hard I forget I'm cramped in economy; On long flights I actually look forward to the Volander more than the movies—they dim the cabin lights and my brain just drifts; I was stuck in the middle seat this time, so I totally missed that moment of Volander I usually get right before we start descending.

Definition: fantasy that there's some elaborate diagnosis out there that neatly captures the kind of person you are, tying together your many flaws and contradictions into a single theme—which wouldn't necessarily sort out the mess inside your head but would at least let you mark it with a little sign so people know to walk around it.
Etymology: Fromsymptom+mania.
Example Sentences: I went down a Symptomania rabbit hole last night and now I'm half-convinced there's a twelve-letter acronym that explains my entire personality; Her Symptomania got so intense she started begging her therapist to just give it a name already" so she could stop feeling like a walking contradiction; We really bonded over our shared Symptomania

Definition: fear of the prospect of not existing one day, feeling like a student about to graduate from the universe, on the cusp of a transition you don't feel ready for.
Etymology: Finnishkadotus, perdition, which once meant "loss" but now means "eternal damnation." Pronounced "kuh-doh."
Example Sentences: I've been having this weird Kadot all week, like I'm standing on the edge of something huge and I can't step back; She tried to laugh it off, but you could tell the Kadot hit her hard after her dad's health scare; On quiet nights, when the house is still, that old Kadot creeps in and I suddenly feel way too aware of how temporary everything is.

Definition: state of having lost all control over how you feel about someone— not even trying to quench the flames anymore, but lighting other fires around your head just hoping to contain the damage.
Etymology: Fromatria, the chambers of the heart +triage, the sorting of patients in hospital admissions, factoring in the urgency of their illness or injury. Pronounced "at-ree-ahzh."
Example Sentences: I thought I was over him, but last night's dream just threw me right back into full-on attriage; She keeps joking about her season of attriage

Definition: frustration that you'll never be able to understand another person's pain, only ever searching their face for some faint evocation of it, then rifling through your own experiences for some slapdash comparison, wishing you could tell them truthfully, "I know exactly how you feel."
Etymology: Latindolor, pain +colorblindness. Pronounced "doh-ler-blahynd-nis."
Example Sentences: Every time my sister talks about her divorce, I'm hit with this wave of Dolorblindness, like I'm grasping for the right thing to say and coming up empty; Sitting with patients all day, you'd think I'd get used to it, but the Dolorblindness never really goes away, it just gets a little quieter; After the funeral, we all kind of sat there in shared Dolorblindness, knowing we cared deeply but still not knowing how to bridge that gap with the right words.

Definition: moment you look around and realize that you're currently happy—consciously trying to savor the feeling—which prompts your intellect to identify it, pick it apart, and put it in context, where it will slowly dissolve until it's little more than an aftertaste.
Etymology: Ancient Greek καιρός (kairos), a sublime or opportune moment + σκλήρωσις (sklḗrōsis), hardening. Pronounced "kahy-roh-skluh-roh-sis."
Example Sentences: I was sitting on the porch with my grandparents, listening to them bicker about nothing, when that familiar kairosclerosis hit and I suddenly couldn't just let the moment be; Sometimes I worry that journaling every night just feeds my kairosclerosis, like I'm dissecting all the good parts of my day instead of living them; Halfway through the concert I felt this wave of kairosclerosis and had to remind myself to stop narrating it in my head and just sing along.
