Definition: an unexpected twinge of attraction for a friend; a flutter of desire you don't necessarily want to feel, that didn't even seem possible up until this point, when it suddenly becomes a problem you have to deal with.
Etymology: Fromfrisson, a shiver of excitement +dribber, an inaccurate archer. Pronounced "dree-sawn."
Example Sentences: I got this weird Drisson when she laughed at my stupid joke, and now I have no idea how to act around her; That whole road trip was fine until that one late-night conversation in the motel lobby, and suddenly—bam—Drisson; I keep telling myself it's nothing, just a little Drisson that'll pass, but it's making every hangout feel way more complicated than it used to be.

Definition: a surge of energy upon catching a glance from someone you like, which scrambles your ungrounded circuits and tempts you to chase after that feeling with a kite and a key.
Etymology: Fromecstatic, deliriously happy +static shock, a charge of potential energy that builds up invisibly until it sparks across the air.
Example Sentences: I swear I felt that Ecstatic Shock hit me the second she looked up and actually remembered my name; Ever since that first Ecstatic Shock in the library, I can't focus around him without my brain short‑circuiting; You could practically see the Ecstatic Shock ripple through her when he walked into the room and smiled in her direction

Definition: feeling of returning from an immersive trip only to notice it fading rapidly from your awareness, as if your brain had automatically assumed it was all just a dream and already went to work scrubbing it from your memory.
Etymology: Germanrückkehren, coming back +Unruhe, restlessness. CompareZugunruhe, "migration restlessness," the fidgety behavior observed in birds approaching migration. Pronounced "rook-kair-oon-roo-uh."
Example Sentences: Shift-Movement; Time-Memory

Definition: alienation from the crude machinery of your own body—like riding a ramshackle parade float that's run by gremlins you can't see, who toil away in darkness, pulling strings to move your limbs, kneading your guts and working the bellows, trying to further your modern agenda using nothing more advanced than a sackful of bones and splanchnic ganglia, zapped by sparks in primordial ooze.
Etymology: Latinvia, by way of +viande, meat. Pronounced "vee-ad-nee."
Example Sentences: Lately the Viadne has been so intense that even brushing my teeth feels like I'm operating some janky robot from three feet behind my eyes; On bad days the Viadne hits halfway through a meeting and I'll suddenly feel like my mouth is just some faulty speaker my thoughts are coming out of; I thought it was just stress, but when I started meditating the Viadne actually got sharper, like I'd stepped even further back from the controls.

Definition: a state of exhaustion inspired by senseless tragedies and acts of violence, which force you to abruptly revise your expectations of what can happen in this world, trying to prop yourself up like an old scarecrow, who's bursting at the seams yet powerless to do anything but stand there and watch.
Etymology: In Japanese mythology,Kuebikois the name of a kami deity, a scarecrow who stands all day watching the world go by, which has made him very wise but locked in place. Pronounced "koo-web-i-koh."
Example Sentences: After the news last night, I just sat on the couch in total Kuebiko and couldn't bring myself to turn the TV back on; She's been in this quiet Kuebiko for weeks now, barely talking, just going through the motions at work; I hit a point of Kuebiko where I had to log off social media completely, because every new headline felt like one more weight I couldn't carry

Definition: a conversation that spans huge intervals of time, kept alive by contributors who casually overlay their thoughts as if no time had passed, which effectively compresses it all into a poignant temporal mash—an online thread that waits years between replies, a constitution being amended by successive generations, or a cave painting fleshed out in sessions ten thousand years apart, by artists who might each have been using the same discarded piece of charcoal.
Etymology: Basqueekurrikatz, a piece of charcoal used for drawing. Pronounced "ek-yuh-ree."
Example Sentences: We're basically adding our own little Ecury to this family recipe notebook every time we scribble in the margins; That comment you just posted on a 12-year-old forum thread is pure Ecury energy; Reading those letters between the two historians felt like stepping into an ongoing Ecury that neither of them expected to outlive them.

Definition: a state of instinctive restlessness that arises when your society makes too many choices on your behalf—foreclosing all risks, codifying all moral dilemmas, deciding in advance whether you'll succeed or fail—as if your conscience had been outsourced to an external provider, so it's no longer necessary to have one on site.
Etymology: Fromnull, an empty set of values.
Example Sentences: Lately I've been feeling this weird Nullness at work, like every decision's already been made for me before I even show up; When she moved back to her hometown, the comfort was nice at first, but the Nullness kicked in once she realized nothing she did really changed anything; He jokes about it, but you can tell the Nullness gets to him whenever he talks about how his whole career path was basically mapped out by his parents and teachers

Definition: habit of falling hard for whatever pretty new acquaintance happens to come along, spending hours wallowing in the handful of details you can gather about them, connecting the dots into elaborate constellations, even imagining an entire future together—images that have no particular purpose, except that they're kinda fun to think about.
Etymology: Hebrew (hikrín), to project an image +hankering, craving. Pronounced "hik-er-ing."
Example Sentences: I know it's just hickering, but I've already planned out our imaginary vacation together after talking to him once at the coffee machine; My roommate's in full-on hickering mode again—she met this guy at trivia night and now she's stalking his Goodreads and building a whole personality for him; I'm trying to focus on my work, but the hickering kicks in every time I replay that five-minute conversation we had on the train.

Definition: a feature of modern civilization that suddenly strikes you as absurd and grotesque—from pets and milk drinking to organ transplants, life insurance, and fiction—part of a rich legacy of absurdity that dates all the way back to the moment our ancestors first hauled themselves out of the slime, but could not for the life of them remember what they got up to do.
Etymology: Acronym of When You Think About It. Pronounced "wahy-tahy."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk through the supermarket at midnight and see those aisles of neon-colored cereal, I get this weird rush of Wytai; Her whole essay was basically a long rant about the Wytai she feels whenever she has to sign yet another terms-of-service agreement; We were sitting in traffic behind a truck full of plastic lawn flamingos, and the Wytai hit us both at the exact same moment.

Definition: subtle but persistent feeling of being out of place, as maladapted to your surroundings as a seal on a beach, lumbering and clumsy, huddled in the company of other misfits, dreaming of life in your natural habitat, a place where you'd be fluidly, brilliantly, effortlessly at home.
Etymology: Ancient Greek μοναχός (monakhós), single, solitary + ὄψις (ópsis), vision. Pronounced "mon-uh-kop-sis."
Example Sentences: I always get this weird wave of monachopsis at big networking events, so I usually sneak out early; Lately the monachopsis has been hitting harder at family gatherings, even though nothing specific is wrong; Moving to a new city helped for a while, but the monachopsis crept back once the novelty wore off.

Definition: a fear you sometimes experience while leaving a loved one, wondering if this will turn out to be the last time you'll ever see them, and whatever slapdash good-bye you toss their way might have to serve as your final farewell.
Etymology: Greek αντίο (antío), farewell + -φοβία (-phobía), fear. Pronounced "an-tee-uh-foh-bee-uh."
Example Sentences: Every time my dad flies back home, my Antiophobia kicks in and I end up hugging him three extra times at the airport; Lately my Antiophobia has gotten so bad that I can't just say bye" on the phone—I always add "I love you" at the end

Definition: a wistful omen of the first sign of autumn—a subtle coolness in the shadows, a rustling of dead leaves abandoned on the sidewalk, or a long skein of geese sweeping over your head like the second hand of a clock.
Etymology: Fromautumn+auspice, an omen, or a divination derived from observing the actions of birds. Pronounced "aw-stis."
Example Sentences: I felt a strange Austice on my walk home last night, even though the calendar still says it's summer; There's this quiet Austice in the air today, like everything's just starting to wind down; Every year my dad starts talking about Austice the moment he sees that first V of geese over the highway.

Definition: complicated solitude of hotel rooms late at night, spending time in a place that's both yours and emphatically not yours, both soulless and homey, both timeless and temporary, suspended somewhere halfway between vacancy and no vacancy.
Etymology: Frominn, a small hotel or tavern for travelers +inanity, a total lack of meaning or ideas. Pronounced "ihn-i-tee."
Example Sentences: I was fine during the conference, but the innity really hit me when I got back to that silent hotel room at midnight; On long work trips I pack my favorite tea and a little candle, just to soften the innity a bit; Walking down those identical carpeted hallways, keycard in hand, I felt that weird mix of freedom and innity settle in again.

Definition: desire to care less about things; to figure out a way to relax your grip on your life and hold it loosely and playfully, keeping it in the air like a volleyball, with quick and fleeting interventions, bouncing freely in the hands of trusted friends, always in play.
Etymology: Italianlibero, free. Aliberois a position on a volleyball team that can move at greater liberty than other players, subbing freely and without permission, with an emphasis on keeping the ball in play. Pronounced "lib-er-oh-sis."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been feeling this weird liberosis, like I don't need to obsess over every little plan anymore; Her move to the coast was pure liberosis, just selling most of her stuff and trusting things would work out; There was a quiet liberosis in the way he laughed off the mistake and just kept going with the presentation.

Definition: off-putting awareness of how deeply your culture's norms are ingrained in your psyche—arbitrarily defining what you find shameful and admirable, private and communal, attractive and repulsive, fair and unfair—as if you'd been programmed in a way that you can't control or even perceive, until you happen to encounter someone who has slightly different code.
Etymology: Ancient Greek ἡμεῖς (hēmeîs), we (excluding the listener). Pronounced "hem-ey-sis."
Example Sentences: I had this weird wave of hemeisis when I realized how shocked I was by how casually they talked about money at dinner; Traveling alone for the first time really hit me with hemeisis—suddenly all my automatic reactions felt like they were running on someone else's script; Our whole seminar turned into a group therapy session about hemeisis after that exchange student questioned why we apologize so much for everything

Definition: a knee-jerk territorial reaction when a friend displays a casual interest in one of your obsessions.
Etymology: Mandarin 粉絲 (fěnsī), fan, admirer + defensiveness. Pronounced "fen-siv-nis."
Example Sentences: I had a flash of pure fensiveness when she said she might start coming to my favorite trivia night every week; His fensiveness kicked in the second Mark mentioned getting into the same obscure band he's loved for years; I'm working on not letting fensiveness ruin things when people show interest in my D&D campaign.

Definition: a flash of real emotion glimpsed in someone sitting across the room— their mind wandering away from whatever's happening around them, their eyes lighting up with pensiveness or vulnerability or cosmic boredom—as if you could see backstage through a gap in the curtains, watching actors in costume mouthing their lines, fragments of bizarre sets waiting for some other production.
Etymology: Fromfata morgana, a kind of mirage that warps the appearance of distant objects so that sailboats look like fairy castles +organa, methods by which a philosophical investigation may be conducted. Pronounced "fah-tuh awr-gah-nuh."
Example Sentences: I was halfway through my presentation when I caught this brief Fata Organa in her expression, like she'd suddenly remembered an entirely different life; On the train yesterday, the guy across from me had this Fata Organa moment where his eyes just drifted off and you could tell he wasn't really seeing the subway anymore; Sometimes I'll see a Fata Organa flicker across your face at parties, and I always wonder what parallel storyline you've slipped into for those few seconds.

Definition: a feeling of resonant connection with an author or artist you'll never meet, who may have lived centuries ago and thousands of miles away but can still get inside your head and leave behind morsels of their experience, like the little piles of stones left by hikers that mark a hidden path through unfamiliar territory.
Etymology: Portuguesemoledro, cairn. According to Portuguese legend, if you take a stone from a cairn and put it under a pillow, in the morning an enchanted soldier will appear for a moment, before transforming back into the stone and returning to the pile. Pronounced "moh-leh-droh."
Example Sentences: I got this weird rush of moledro rereading Rilke last night, like he was sitting on the couch next to me; Every time I walk out of a museum with a new favorite painter, I'm buzzing with moledro for the rest of the day; That podcast about medieval poets hit me so hard I had to pause it and just sit with the moledro for a minute.

Definition: finding yourself bothered by somebody's death more than you would have expected, even if they were only an abstract presence in your life, like a lighthouse in the distance that suddenly goes dark, leaving you with one less landmark to navigate by.
Etymology: In navigation,dead reckoningis the practice of using your prior course to extrapolate your subsequent position. It can be useful on starless nights but often leads to cumulative errors; if you don't often check your position against new data, you might end up completely lost.
Example Sentences: Ever since the news about his favorite author broke, he's been in this weird state of Dead Reckoning, like he lost someone he actually knew; I didn't expect that random podcaster's passing to hit me so hard either—it was pure Dead Reckoning for a week; She joked that her whole playlist was just songs she'd found during bouts of Dead Reckoning after various celebrities died.

Definition: sadness that you'll never really know what other people think of you, whether good, bad, or if at all—that although you can gather a few hints here and there, and even ask around for honest feedback, you'll always have to wonder which opinions are being softened out of flattery, sharpened out of malice, or held back because it's simply not their place.
Etymology: In Ancient Rome, thecatoptric cistulawas a kind of mirror-lined box whose interior appeared to expand into an infinite forest, library, or treasure room. Pronounced "kuh-top-trik tris-tes."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been hit with this weird Catoptric Tristesse whenever I scroll through old photos and wonder what everyone actually thought of me back then; Sometimes after big presentations I get this wave of Catoptric Tristesse, like no matter how many compliments I get, I'll never really know how it all landed; We ended up talking till 2 a.m. about relationships, boundaries, and that low-key Catoptric Tristesse that creeps in when you overthink how people see you

Definition: nervously aware how much of your self-image is based on untested assumptions about yourself—only ever guessing how you'd react to a violent threat, a sudden windfall, a huge responsibility, or being told to do something you knew was wrong.
Etymology: North Frisianflicht, maybe. Pronounced "flik-tish."
Example Sentences: I always get a little Flichtish before performance reviews, like I'm about to find out whether I'm actually the person I think I am at work; Talking to my brother after his accident made me weirdly Flichtish about how I'd handle something like that if it happened to me; That movie left me feeling so Flichtish on the drive home, wondering if I'd really make the same choices the main character did.

Definition: inexplicable urge to push people away, even close friends whose company you generally enjoy—like a poker player who keeps folding a promising hand in order to avoid the pain of losing, or tamp down the urge to go all-in.
Etymology: GermanMauerbauer, wall-builder +Traurigkeit, sadness. Pronounced "mou-er-bou-er-trou-rikh- kahyt."
Example Sentences: Letztens hatte ich wieder so eine Phase von Mauerbauertraurigkeit und hab alle Nachrichten einfach ignoriert; Meine Therapeutin meinte, die Mauerbauertraurigkeit sei ein Signal, dass ich mich überfordert fühle, nicht dass ich alle Kontakte abbrechen muss; Wenn du merkst, dass dich diese Mauerbauertraurigkeit packt, schreib mir einfach kurz, damit ich weiß, dass es nicht an mir liegt.

Definition: shocked upon looking twice at something you see every day and catching an obvious detail you'd never noticed before—an old scar on your loved one's knee, a wall in your house that's apparently always been purple, or a prominent building that seemed to appear in your neighborhood overnight—which makes you wonder how much else of your world you might be missing, when you're just barely there yourself.
Etymology: Macedonian поглед (pogled), a glimpse. Pronounced "pog-uhld."
Example Sentences: I just stood there completely poggled, staring at the fridge and realizing the handle's been on the other side this whole time; Walking past the library, I got weirdly poggled noticing that huge mural on the side—has that seriously always been there?; She looked down at her own hands, suddenly poggled by the little crescent scar on her thumb she swears she's never seen before

Definition: feeling of emptiness after a long and arduous process is finally complete—having finished school, recovered from surgery, or gone home at the end of your wedding—which leaves you relieved that it's over but missing the stress that organized your life into a mission.
Etymology: Norwegianetter, after +råtne, decay. Pronounced "et-er-rath."
Example Sentences: I thought I'd be nothing but thrilled when the trial ended, but the Etterath hit me on the drive home and I just sat in the car for an hour; She warned me about the Etterath that comes after defending your thesis, but I didn't believe her until I woke up the next day with no emails to answer; We'd been planning that concert for months, and the morning after, the Etterath was so strong I almost wished we still had a to-do list.

Definition: a hollow place in your psyche that can never be filled; a bottomless hunger for more food, more praise, more attention, more affection, more joy, more sex, more money, more hours of sunshine, more years of your life; a state of panic that everything good will be taken from you too early, which makes you want to swallow the world before it ends up swallowing you.
Etymology: Onomatopoeic to the sound of a devouring maw. Pronounced "hawkh," with air drawn sharply inward through the mouth.
Example Sentences: Desire-Longing; Sadness-Displeasure

Definition: feeling ashamed after revealing a little too much of yourself to someone—allowing them too clear a view of your pettiness, your anger, your cowardice, your childlike vulnerability—wishing you could somehow take back the moment, discreetly bolting the door after a storm had already blown it off its hinges.
Etymology: Scottish Gaelicfoillsich, to expose.
Example Sentences: I've been so foilsick all day after that rant I went on in the meeting; Every time I see her name pop up in my messages, I get this little wave of foilsick remembering what I admitted last weekend; He laughed it off, but you could tell he went a bit foilsick the second he realized how honest he'd just been.

Definition: disquieting awareness that someone's importance to you and your importance to them may not necessarily match—that your best friend might only think of you as a buddy, that someone you barely know might consider you a mentor, that someone you love unconditionally might have one or two conditions.
Etymology: Portuguesefalésia, cliff. A cliff is a dizzying meeting point between high ground and low ground. Pronounced "fuh-lee-zhuh."
Example Sentences: I got this wave of Falesia after realizing I knew everything about her life, but she barely remembered my birthday; Sometimes Falesia hits me when I see how excited I am to text someone who only replies with one-word answers; That scene in the movie wrecked me because it captured that exact feeling of Falesia between the two sisters.

Definition: degree to which your view of the world is warped by your own presence in it, whether you're a stunning beauty who assumes all strangers are chatty, a bully who thinks the world is perpetually at war, or a quivering leaf who walks around in an artificial cloud of deference; the awareness that although you'd like to think you perceive things cleanly and objectively, you've never felt the vibe of a room that doesn't happen to have you in it.
Etymology: Germaneigen, inherent +Anschauung, view. CompareWeltanschauung, "worldview." YourWeltanschauungis how you see the world; yourEigenschauungis a reflection of how the world sees you. Pronounced "ahy-guhn-shou-oong."
Example Sentences: Every time I reread my old journals, I'm struck by how much my Eigenschauung distorted what I thought people were thinking about me; Her whole speech was interesting, but it was so soaked in her own Eigenschauung that it was hard to take any of her conclusions at face value; After therapy, I've started catching those little moments of Eigenschauung in real time, like when I assume everyone's annoyed just because I'm in a bad mood.

Definition: feeling guilty that you care about your own petty concerns more deeply than faraway cataclysms—that a family spat hurts more than a civil war, that a three-day fever hits you harder than climate change.
Etymology: Japanese 近視 (kinshi), near-sightedness. A word just shy ofkinship. Pronounced "kin-chee."
Example Sentences: I've been stuck in this weird Kinchy all week, stressing about my deadline while the news keeps getting worse; She admitted she felt a bit Kinchy canceling brunch over a headache when her group chat was full of stories about floods and evacuations; That movie left me with this lingering Kinchy, like my breakup drama shouldn't weigh so much when the world is literally on fire.

Definition: suddenly aware of how limited your social circles really are; that although your immediate environment feels like a microcosm of society, it's more like a bag of exotic fish floating on the surface of a huge aquarium, which is teeming with a million shadowy subcultures that you'd be stunned to see up close.
Etymology: Fromhobnob, to mix socially +gobsmacked, astounded.
Example Sentences: I was totally Hobsmacked at that conference when I realized I didn't recognize a single name on the speaker list; Scrolling through that subreddit for the first time left me Hobsmacked at how many niche communities are out there that I've never even heard of; After moving to the city, I was Hobsmacked during my first week at work, seeing how everyone had these whole separate worlds I'd never even imagined.

Definition: hollow feeling of having gotten exactly what you thought you wanted, only to learn that it didn't make you happy.
Etymology: In sports, theendzoneis the final goal, the end of the line—but at a certain point you have to drop the ball.
Example Sentences: I finally got the promotion I'd been grinding for, but by the end of the week I just felt completely Endzoned; She thought moving to the city would fix everything, but a few months in she was already texting me about how Endzoned she felt; Winning that big case should've been a high point, yet on the ride home I was weirdly Endzoned instead of excited

Definition: fear that the role you once occupied in someone's life could be refilled without a second thought, which makes you wish that every breakup would include a severance package, a non-compete clause, and some sort of romantic placement program.
Etymology: Greek όχι πια (óchi pia), not anymore. Pronounced "oh-kee-zee-uh."
Example Sentences: I got hit with a wave of ochisia when I saw his new girlfriend posting photos from the exact same hiking spot we used to go to; Ever since the divorce, the ochisia creeps in whenever I think about him laughing at someone else's jokes the way he used to laugh at mine; She joked about needing a lawyer to handle her ochisia, like she wanted a formal contract saying her ex couldn't recycle their old routines with the next person.

Definition: a random image from your distant past that leaps back into your attention, that doesn't mean much of anything but is somehow able to keep fighting against the current, swimming back and forth in your mind, still developing.
Etymology: After a species of salmon,Oncorhynchus keta, which "run" upstream to spawn every year, leaping back to the place they were born; they're not worth much commercially, but the ketas don't know that. When we look back on our lives, it's not just the moments that we remember, not the grand gestures and catered ceremonies, or the world we capture poised and smiling in photos. It's the little things—the minutes—the cheap raw material of ordinary time. Pronounced "kay-tuh."
Example Sentences: not the grand gestures and catered ceremonies

Definition: sense that you're just making it up as you go along—knowing that if someone asked why you do most things, you couldn't really come up with a convincing explanation.
Etymology: In Ancient Rome,Ludi Osci, the Oscan Games, gave rise to the art of improvisational theater. Pronounced "loo-dee-oh-sis."
Example Sentences: Sometimes the ludiosis hits me hardest at work, like I'm just improvising adulthood with no script; After a long talk with my therapist, I realized my constant ludiosis is why I keep changing careers every few years; We were sitting on the rooftop at 2 a.m., laughing about our shared ludiosis and how none of us actually knows what we're doing with our lives.

Definition: a feeling of irrelevance from the broader forces of history; the sense that your life has no relationship to any great mission, no generational hardship, not even an enemy—feeling as harmless as a droplet skittering down a window, that could've just as easily taken part in a tidal wave.
Etymology: Latindys-, bad +historia, history. Pronounced "dis-toh-ree-uh."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been stuck in this weird Dystoria, like I'm just watching life happen instead of actually being part of it; Sometimes I scroll through old photos of my grandparents and the war years and it throws my own Dystoria into sharp relief; The movie hit me harder than I expected, because it captured that quiet Dystoria I've never really been able to put into words.

Definition: a weird little flaw built into your partner that somehow only endears them more to you, in the way that impurities dissolved in water are what allow it to conduct electricity—if all the imperfections were removed, there would be no spark.
Etymology: Middle Englishfawteles, without a defect. Pronounced "faw-tuhl."
Example Sentences: I know it sounds cheesy, but her constant off-key singing in the shower is totally my favorite Fawtle; We were talking about our Fawtles last night, and he said mine is the way I always have to re-check the door three times before we leave; That little eye-roll he does when he's pretending not to laugh has become such a Fawtle to me that I'd actually miss it if he stopped.

Definition: fear of speaking off the cuff or from the heart; the terror of saying the wrong thing and having to watch someone's smile fade as they realize you're not who they thought you were.
Etymology: Ancient Greek μῶμος (momos), blemish, disgrace + -φοβία (-phobía), fear. Momus was the Ancient Greek god of mockery and harsh criticism. Pronounced "moh-muh-foh-bee-uh."
Example Sentences: I used to think I was just shy, but my therapist said a lot of it is actually Momophobia; That moment before I hit send" on a risky text

Definition: an important part of your personality that others seldom see—a secret flaw, a hidden talent, trauma that never comes up, dreams you never mention—that remains a vital part of who you are even if nobody knows it's there, like the sprawling archives in the attics of museums, packed with works far too priceless to risk being displayed for the public.
Etymology: From akeep, the innermost tower of a castle.
Example Sentences: I feel like her keep is this whole other world of ambitions she's never really talked about with anyone; He jokes around all the time, but you can tell there's a keep he's guarding pretty carefully; Everyone has a keep they retreat to when things get overwhelming, even if they never put it into words

Definition: otherworldly atmosphere just before 5 a.m., when the bleary melodrama of an extremely late night becomes awkwardly conflated with the industrious fluorescence of a very early morning.
Etymology: Frenchaubade, an ode to the morning +abattoir, slaughterhouse. Pronounced "oh-bah-dwahr."
Example Sentences: By the time we stumbled out of the club into the empty street, the whole city felt wrapped in that weird aubadoir; I always get my best writing done in the aubadoir, when the world is half-asleep and half-setting up for the day; We sat in the diner through the aubadoir, watching truckers come in for coffee while our last round of cocktails went warm on the table

Definition: sense that you were born too early in history, all too aware of how crude and backward the present can be, feeling tired of having to sit through so much clunky exposition and slow-burning suspense, when all you want to do is skip ahead to find out what happens next.
Etymology: A word tantalizingly close to being the last word of the dictionary, but not quite there. Pronounced "zee-zhah."
Example Sentences: I've been feeling so much Zysia lately that even small talk at parties exhausts me; She channels her Zysia into writing these wild sci‑fi stories about people time-jumping past the boring parts of history; When the news cycle gets overwhelming, his Zysia kicks in and he just logs off everything for a few days.

Definition: a friendship that can lie dormant for years only to pick right back up instantly, as if you'd seen each other last week—which is all the more remarkable given that certain other people can make every lull in conversation feel like an eternity.
Etymology: Fromlifelong+lie low. Pronounced "lahy-loh."
Example Sentences: I finally saw Maya again after six years, and it was such a Lilo that we were laughing like teenagers within five minutes; Honestly, I treasure our Lilo more than the friendships I see every day, because it never feels forced; When I moved back to town, I was nervous to reach out to him, but the moment we met for coffee, it turned into a full-on Lilo and we talked until the café closed

Definition: frustration that you're not enjoying an experience as much as you should, which prompts you to try plugging in various thought combinations to trigger anything more intense than roaring static, as if your heart had been inadvertently demagnetized by a surge of expectations.
Etymology: Fromwend, to wander unpredictably along a predetermined path. Comparethe bends, which occurs when a diver ascends too quickly and gas bubbles begin to form in their tissues, a condition that can be debilitating or fatal.
Example Sentences: I really wanted to love that concert, but halfway through I could feel The Wends creeping in and I just couldn't shake it; Every time I go on one of those trip of a lifetime" vacations

Definition: anger about an injustice you only discovered long after the fact, after years have passed and everyone else has moved on, leaving you seething with an awkward and antiquated righteousness that you're not sure what to do with, like a flywheel still spinning long after the engine is shut off.
Etymology: Fromarchi-, earlier, primitive +acrimony, bitterness, animosity. Pronounced "ahr-kuh-moh-nee."
Example Sentences: I didn't feel the archimony until I reread those old emails and realized how badly they'd treated you; Every time I drive past that place, the archimony comes back, even though everyone else seems to have forgotten what happened there; She laughed it off at first, but you could tell the archimony hit her later, once she'd had time to really piece together what they did.

Definition: act of deliberately squandering your time, lazing about as if none of this is worth a damn, letting precious hours spool away slowly like the string of a runaway kite.
Etymology: Frommog, to enjoy one's self in a quiet, easy, comfortable manner +folly, a foolish act.
Example Sentences: I was supposed to finish my paper this weekend, but I just ended up in full Mogging Folly mode, scrolling my phone for hours; Every time we hang out at his place, it turns into this cozy Mogging Folly afternoon with music, snacks, and zero plans; She called me at noon to check in, and I had to admit I was still in bed, deep in my Mogging Folly era.

Definition: point in your mid-twenties when your youthfulness expires as a valid excuse, leaving you accountable for your own station in life, even if you're still only reeling from your past or planning for the future— which somehow makes time itself feel more urgent than before, until even the springtime pollen floating in the air reminds you of the coming snow.
Etymology: Borrowed from the traditional feast of the summer solstice, after which all the days become shorter.
Example Sentences: I hit my midsummer right around 26, when hangovers got worse and figuring it out" stopped sounding cute; She keeps joking that her midsummer arrived the day she realized she relates more to the parents than the teens in movies; It feels like you're going through your own midsummer right now

Definition: a certain person who embodies all the things you like the least about yourself—a seeming caricature of your worst tendencies—which leaves you feeling repulsed and fascinated in equal measure, having stumbled upon a role model of exactly the kind of person you never want to be.
Etymology: Latinmalus, bad +typus, a kind of sculptor's mold. A mold is essentially a negative image of the object you want to sculpt—so if you're trying to shape yourself, perhaps a good first step is to scoop away the negative space. Pronounced "mal-uh-tahyp."
Example Sentences: Every time I get stuck in my head about work, I remind myself not to turn into my old boss, who is basically my Malotype; When I met her, it was like watching my Malotype walk into the room and start talking over everyone; I try to be nice, but seeing my Malotype on social media is the best motivation to double-check my own behavior.

Definition: wish that the modern world felt as epic as the one depicted in old stories and folktales—a place of tragedy and transcendence, of oaths and omens and fates, where everyday life felt like a quest for glory, a mythic bond with an ancient past, or a battle for survival against a clear enemy, rather than an open-ended parlor game where all the rules are made up and the points don't matter.
Etymology: Fromring, a key element in many sagas and myths + -lorn, sorely missing. Pronounced "ring- lawrn."
Example Sentences: Sometimes when I'm stuck in traffic under these gray office towers, I get weirdly ringlorn and start daydreaming about dragons and prophecies instead; She's been so ringlorn lately that she's planning a hiking trip to all those old castle ruins just to feel like she's in a saga; Watching that movie again made me ringlorn for a world where people still swore oaths by the stars and actually meant them

Definition: feeling quietly overjoyed to be the only one awake in the middle of the night—sitting alone with a laptop and a cup of tea or strolling down the center line of an abandoned street—taking in the world like an empty theater between productions, stripped down to a simple black box, open to be whatever you want it to be.
Etymology: FromNyctocereus, a genus of cactus that blooms only at night. Pronounced "nik-tuhs."
Example Sentences: I always get a little nyctous when everyone's gone to bed and it's just me, the hum of the fridge, and my notebook; That 3 a.m. walk back from the party was weirdly nyctous, like the whole city had paused just for us; Lately I've been chasing that nyctous feeling by staying up to edit photos while the house is completely silent.

Definition: moment you realize you are changing as a person, finally outgrowing your old problems like a reptile shedding its skin, already able to twist back around and chuckle at this weirdly antiquated caricature of yourself that will soon come off completely.
Etymology: Fromapolysis, the stage of molting when an invertebrate's shell begins to separate from the skin beneath it +adultus, sacrificed. Pronounced "ah-pahl-i-tuhs."
Example Sentences: I had this weird Apolytus on the train home last night and suddenly all the drama from last year just felt… tiny; She said her Apolytus hit her in the middle of cleaning out her closet, like she was literally throwing away the person she used to be; Ever since that Apolytus after my breakup, I've been able to talk about my past without getting defensive, almost like I'm gossiping about someone I used to know

Definition: a tiny jolt of awareness that someday you will die, which leaves you lying awake in bed whispering silently to yourself, Oh, right, this is it; an unsettling reminder that your life is not just a game you're playing or a story you'll be telling later, but your one and only glimpse of what the universe has to offer, like a kid waking up in the back seat of the family car at night, having just pulled into a bright neon gas station, looking around for a moment or two, before settling back in for the long road trip, sleeping for miles and miles off into the dark.
Etymology: Latinmorituri, "we who are about to die." Pronounced "moh-rich-uh-riz-uhm.
Example Sentences: I was brushing my teeth when this wave of moriturism hit me out of nowhere, and I just stood there staring at myself in the mirror; Every time I visit my grandparents, I get this quiet moriturism on the drive home that makes me want to call everyone I care about; The movie was supposed to be a light comedy, but that final scene triggered such intense moriturism that we all left the theater in total silence.

Definition: state of not knowing how you really feel about something, which forces you to sift through clues hidden in your own behavior, as if you were some other person—noticing a twist of acid in your voice, an obscene amount of effort you put into something trifling, or an inexplicable weight on your shoulders that makes it difficult to get out of bed.
Etymology: Ancient Greek ἄγνωστος (ágnōstos), not knowing + διάθεσις (diáthesis), condition, mood. Pronounced "ag-nos-thee-zhuh."
Example Sentences: Lately I've been stuck in this weird agnosthesia about my job, like I can't tell if I'm burned out or just bored; That whole week after the breakup was pure agnosthesia—I kept replaying our conversations just to figure out what I actually felt; I always journal when I'm in that kind of agnosthesia, hoping the patterns in what I write will tell me more than my own head does.

Definition: strange wistfulness of used bookstores, which are somehow infused with the passage of time—filled with thousands of old books you'll never have time to read, each of which is itself locked in its own era, bound and dated and papered over like an old room the author abandoned years ago, a hidden annex littered with thoughts left just as they were on the day they were captured.
Etymology: Fromvellum, parchment +ichor, the fluid that flows in the veins of the gods in Ancient Greek mythology. Pronounced "vel-uh-kawr."
Example Sentences: Every time I walk past that little secondhand shop on the corner, I get this wave of vellichor and have to go in, even if I'm already late; There was so much vellichor in that dusty attic, with boxes of old paperbacks stacked to the ceiling, that I ended up spending the whole afternoon up there; I know it's weird, but I actually travel with a list of indie bookshops to visit, just to chase that vellichor in different cities

Definition: tranquil pleasure of being near a gathering but not quite in it— hovering on the perimeter of a campfire, talking quietly outside a party, resting your eyes in the back seat of a car listening to friends chatting up front—feeling blissfully invisible yet still fully included, safe in the knowledge that everyone is together and everyone is okay, with all the thrill of being there without the burden of having to be.
Etymology: Middle Englishmidding, alternate spelling ofmidden, a refuse heap that sits near a dwelling. Pronounced "mid-ing."
Example Sentences: I'll probably just be midding on the couch while you all play board games, if that's okay; There's this perfect little corner table at the café where I can sit midding while everyone else chats around me; After a long week, I love midding in the back seat on late-night drives, just listening to you guys talk up front.

Definition: an incantation whispered privately to yourself to celebrate the loss of something or someone you loved, which almost makes it feel like a deliberate renunciation, consciously deciding to relinquish them to an earlier part of your life.
Etymology: Latinsolla, whole, unbroken + Sesothofasolla, to disconnect + Estonianlas olla, let it be. Pronounced "suh-lah, suh-lah, suh-lah."
Example Sentences: Dès Vu

Definition: moment of realization that your quintessential future self isn't ever going to show up, which forces the role to fall upon the understudy, the gawky kid who spent years mouthing their lines in the wings before being shoved into the glare of your life, which is already well into its second act.
Etymology: Frommean, common, humble, low-grade +the meantime, the time spent waiting for some other event to occur.
Example Sentences: I think turning 30 hit me hard because that's when The Meantime really set in for me; After the divorce, she said The Meantime finally pushed her to stop waiting and actually start the business she'd been daydreaming about; We were sitting on his balcony at 2 a.m., talking about The Meantime and laughing at how unprepared we both felt to be the main characters in our own lives

Definition: something you've misunderstood for years without knowing it—a familiar word with a weird pronunciation, a favorite saying that means the opposite of what you thought, a well-known factoid that was disproven years ago while you weren't looking—making you want to stress-test the foundations of your understanding of reality.
Etymology: A mispronunciation of the Frenchvoilà, "behold!" Pronounced "wawl-uh."
Example Sentences: I had a total wollah moment when I realized butt naked" isn't actually "buck naked

Definition: maddening thrill of an ambiguous flirtation, which quivers in tension halfway between platonic and romantic—maybe, but no, but maybe—leaving you guessing what's going on inside their chest, forced to assume that at any given moment their attraction is both alive and dead at the same time.
Etymology: Frenchsourire, smile +frisson, a shiver of chill or excitement. Pronounced "soo-freez."
Example Sentences: I swear that whole train ride with Jamie was pure Soufrise, and now I can't stop replaying every little glance in my head; There's this weird Soufrise between them at work, like everyone can feel it but no one dares bring it up; By the end of the night the Soufrise was so intense that I had to leave early just to clear my head.

Definition: unconscious habit of looking at someone and seeing only a cartoon of what they represent to you, their face obscured by a superimposed image of someone else entirely—your mother, your school bully, or yourself in another time—which makes you wonder what others must see when they look at you from across the room.
Etymology: Fromelse. Pronounced "el-sing."
Example Sentences: I caught myself Elsing again in that meeting and had to consciously remind my brain, That's not Dad

Definition: an unassuming feature of our daily lives that will eventually come off as the bizarre relic of a bygone era, that'll make us look back in shock that we ever thought it was normal to bless each other's sneezes, drive cars by hand, swim in chlorinated pools, keep animals in zoos, or feel clean using little else but toilet paper—things that we never think to question, because that's just what people did "back then."
Etymology: Fromboor, an ill-mannered person +hence, in the future from now. Pronounced "boor-uhns."
Example Sentences: I wonder what everyday habit now is going to be seen as total boorance in a hundred years; My grandpa talks about smoking on airplanes like it was nothing, and it just sounds like pure boorance to me; One day our kids are going to look back at us commuting for hours in traffic and say, Wow

Definition: a solitary experience you wish you could have shared with someone else—having dinner in a romantic setting, reaching the summit after an arduous climb, having a run-in with a crazy stranger that nobody's going to believe—which makes you look around for confirmation that it even happened at all.
Etymology: Welshsi-so, see-saw, an invention that can only ever be enjoyed by multiple people; when used alone, it's just a wonky bench. Pronounced "see-soh."
Example Sentences: Last night's sunset on the pier was such a total siso that I almost called you just to prove it was real; That hike I did alone in Peru was amazing, but the view at the top turned into this weird siso that still feels like a dream; I had this insane siso on the subway today and now I'm kicking myself that no one else was there to witness it.

Definition: otherworldly aura of seeing recordings of a friend in early childhood—catching those little gestures you'd one day come to know, so recognizable yet so foreign, searching their eyes for traces of who it is they'd eventually become.
Etymology: Fromalpha, the unstable initial release of software still being tested +exposure, the amount of time that light is allowed onto photographic film.
Example Sentences: I was going through my old camcorder tapes yesterday and had this weird Alpha Exposure moment watching you toddle around in that dinosaur sweater; Every time my mom sends me a grainy video of us from kindergarten, I get hit with this intense Alpha Exposure, like I'm meeting tiny versions of people I already know too well; Sitting with your dad as he paused the footage to point out your little mannerisms was such peak Alpha Exposure that I couldn't stop staring at your face, trying to match it to the you I know now

Definition: a long-overdue argument that shakes up a relationship, burning wildly through your issues like a forest fire, which clears out your dry and hollow grievances and reminds you that your roots run deeper than you think.
Etymology: Middle Englishfardel, burden or bundle +din, a loud cacophonous noise. Pronounced "fahr-dl- din."
Example Sentences: We'd been tiptoeing around everything for months, so when the Fardle Din finally hit last night, it was almost a relief; After that whole Fardle Din with my sister, we're weirdly closer now and actually talking about stuff instead of just pretending; I'm kind of bracing myself, because if we keep avoiding this, it's going to turn into a full-on Fardle Din over the holidays.

Definition: unhinged delirium of being alone for an extended period of time— feeling the hours stretch into days until a weird little culture begins to form inside your head, with its own superstitions and alternate histories and a half-mumbled dialect all your own—whose freewheeling absurdity feels oddly liberating but makes it that much harder to reacclimate to the strictures and ambiguities of normal social life.
Etymology: Fromsolitary, being by oneself +asylum, a sanctuary for the mentally ill +Elysium, the Ancient Greek equivalent of heaven. Pronounced "soh-lee-zee-uhm."
Example Sentences: After three weeks at the cabin with no cell service, I was deep in Solysium and talking back to the creaks in the floorboards; Coming back to the office after that kind of Solysium is brutal—I kept forgetting how to make small talk and just zoning out; She warned me that if I moved to that tiny island alone, I'd better have a plan for when the Solysium inevitably kicked in.

Definition: amniotic tranquility of being indoors during a thunderstorm.
Etymology: Latinchrysalis, the pupa of a butterfly. Pronounced "kris-uh-liz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Every time it rains like this, I get this overwhelming sense of chrysalism and never want to leave the couch; She painted the scene so vividly that you could almost feel the chrysalism she was trying to capture; Lately I've been craving that late-night chrysalism we used to share at your old apartment when storms rolled in.

Definition: an abrupt collapse of trust in yourself—having abandoned a resolution, surrendered to your demons, or squandered an opportunity you swore you'd take seriously this time—which resets your expectations and makes it that much harder to guarantee that your word is worth anything, even to yourself.
Etymology: In economics, a loss of backing is when the government no longer guarantees the value of a certain currency, particularly when it's not exchangeable for anything physical like gold or silver, thus it only retains value because we say it does.
Example Sentences: After that loss of backing last year, I promised myself I'd stop making big declarations I can't follow through on; The loss of backing I felt after skipping the interview really stuck with me, so now I triple‑check before I commit to anything; She said the real damage wasn't the breakup itself, but the loss of backing that made her question every promise she makes to herself now.

Definition: imaginary committee of elders that keeps a running log of all your mistakes, steadily building their case that you're secretly a fraud, a coward, a doofus, and a douche—who would've revoked your good fortune years ago had they not been hampered by their own bitter squabblings over proper grammar and spelling.
Etymology: Old Englishgilt, awareness of wrongdoing +wrought, shaped with hammers. Pronounced "thegilt-rahyts."
Example Sentences: Every time I send an email with a typo, I can practically hear The Giltwrights adding it to my permanent record; When my boss praised my presentation, I swear I felt The Giltwrights glaring at me from the rafters; I was about to apply for that promotion, but then The Giltwrights started whispering in my head again, so I chickened out.

Definition: awareness of how fundamentally limited your senses are—noticing how little of your field of vision is ever in focus, how few colors you're able to see, how few sounds you're able to hear, and how intrusively your brain fills in the blanks with its own cartoonish extrapolations—which makes you wish you could experience the whole of reality instead of only evercatching a tiny glimpse of it, to just once step back from the keyhole and finally open the door.
Etymology: Italianocchiolino("little eye"), the original name that Galileo gave to the microscope in 1609. Pronounced "oh-kyoh-liz-uhm."
Example Sentences: Senses-Perception; Sight-Sound

Definition: a sense of paradoxical relief when something bad happens to you, which temporarily lowers your own expectations for yourself, transforming a faceless protagonist into something of an underdog, who's that much easier to root for.
Etymology: GermanLeiden, suffering +Freude, joy. CompareSchadenfreude, joy at the misfortune of others. Pronounced "lahyd-n-froi-duh.:
Example Sentences: I felt this weird wave of Leidenfreude after I bombed the presentation, like, Okay

Definition: feeling grateful to be stranded in a place where you can't do much of anything—sitting for hours at an airport gate, the sleeper car of a train, or the backseat of a van on a long road trip—which temporarily alleviates the burden of being able to do anything at any time and frees up your brain to do whatever it wants to do, even if it's just to flicker your eyes across the passing landscape.
Etymology: FromIdlewild, the original name of John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City.
Example Sentences: I actually kind of love that long layover feeling—there's this weird Idlewild that hits once I've answered all my emails and there's nothing left to do but stare out the window; On that overnight bus to Denver, I slipped into a cozy Idlewild, just listening to podcasts and watching the highway lights blur by; Being snowed in at the cabin gave me this unexpected Idlewild, like the universe had pressed pause and told me I didn't have to be productive for a while.

Definition: paradoxical urge to avoid doing something you've been looking forward to—opening a decisive letter, meeting up with a friend who's finally back in town, reading a new book from your favorite author—perpetually waiting around for the right state of mind, stretching out the bliss of anticipation as long as you can.
Etymology: Latinpro-, forward +reluctans, resisting. Pronounced "proh-luhk-tuhns."
Example Sentences: I could feel this weird proluctance creeping in as I stared at the unopened acceptance email, even though I'd been waiting for it all week; My proluctance was so strong that I kept circling the bookstore for half an hour before finally buying the novel I'd preordered months ago; She laughed at her own proluctance, admitting she'd delayed texting him back for days just to savor the possibility of what he might say.

Definition: feeling trapped inside your own language, struggling to shake away the baggage weighing down certain words, unable to break out of its age-old structures and melodies, frustrated that the scattering of verbal pigments on its palette could never quite capture the colors in your head.
Etymology: Fromhem, an attempt to clear the throat +jaw, coarse babble.
Example Sentences: Every time I try to write poetry in English, I end up totally hem jawed and close the notebook; She looked hem jawed during the meeting, like she had a dozen ways to say it in her head but none of them would come out right; I get so hem jawed when I'm talking about this stuff that I just switch to drawing instead.

Definition: lulling isolation of driving late at night—floating through the void in an otherworldly hum, trailing red jewels in the darkness, your high beams sweeping back and forth like a lighthouse.
Etymology: Hungarianmerre, where? in which direction? Pronounced "mair-uhn-nis."
Example Sentences: Every time I take that empty highway home after midnight, the Merrenness hits me so hard I almost don't want the drive to end; There was this strange Merrenness on the road last night, like I was the only person left in the world, just following those red taillights; I put on a long ambient playlist specifically to lean into the Merrenness on those late solo drives back from the cabin
